  • The term encompasses the deliberate intent to deceive or commit fraud by introducing a child into a family lineage under false pretences.
  • This is a significant concept in forensic and legal contexts, especially in cases involving inheritance disputes, fraud, or the falsification of lineage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Posthumous child: This term refers to a child born after the death of a parent, typically the father. It does not relate to the act of presenting another's child as one's own.

 

Option B) Fictional child: While this term could conceptually align with fabricating the existence of a child, it does not specifically denote the legal or forensic act of presenting another's living child as one's own for inheritance or legal purposes.

 

Option D) Both B and C: Although "fictional child" could loosely relate to the concept of fabricating a child's existence or identity, "Suppositious Child" is the precise term used in legal and forensic contexts to describe the act in question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A "suppositious child" is fraudulently presented as one's own for financial gain, unlike a "posthumous child," born after the father's death, or a "fictional child," which is purely imaginary.

questions.text: On chronic use, which of the following drugs may cause reversible gynaecomastia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cimetidine

 

  • Cimetidine, a histamine H2 receptor antagonist used to treat peptic ulcer disease and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), can cause reversible gynecomastia on chronic use.
  • This side effect is thought to be due to cimetidine's antiandrogenic activity, including its ability to block dihydrotestosterone binding to androgen receptors and inhibit the enzyme cytochrome P450, which can disrupt normal hormone metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Omeprazole: A proton pump inhibitor used for similar indications as cimetidine but does not commonly cause gynecomastia.

 

Option C. Pirenzepine: An antimuscarinic agent used less frequently in peptic ulcer disease, not typically associated with gynecomastia.

 

Option D. Sucralfate: A medication used to treat ulcers by forming a protective barrier on the ulcer surface. It is not associated with gynecomastia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cimetidine can cause reversible gynecomastia when used chronically due to its antiandrogenic properties.
  • This side effect is relatively unique among drugs used for gastric acid-related disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs, a selective V2 receptor agonist, is specifically indicated for treating central diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Desmopressin

 

  • Desmopressin is a synthetic analogue of vasopressin with a strong selectivity for the V2 receptors, which are primarily located in the renal collecting ducts.
  • Its action on these receptors increases water reabsorption, making it highly effective in the treatment of central diabetes insipidus, a condition characterized by a deficiency of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) leading to excessive urine production and thirst.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arginine vasopressin: While this is the natural form of ADH and does have effects on V2 receptors, it is not as selective as desmopressin and has significant action on V1 receptors, which are associated with vasoconstriction.

 

Option C. Lypressin: Another synthetic analogue of vasopressin, but less commonly used compared to desmopressin due to its profile of action and availability.

 

Option D. Terlipressin: Mainly acts on V1 receptors and is used in the management of variceal bleeding and hepatorenal syndrome, not central diabetes insipidus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Desmopressin is the treatment of choice for central diabetes insipidus due to its selective action on V2 receptors in the renal collecting ducts, which increases water reabsorption and reduces urine output.

questions.text: Which of these is the most likely explanation for venous ulcers in patients with varicose veins?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ambulatory venous hypertension

 

  • At present, ambulatory venous hypertension is the only accepted underlying cause of venous ulceration.
  • This also explains why venous ulcers are never seen in the upper limb.
  • It is important to try to define the exact mechanism of ulcer development.
  • Venous hypertension may be the result of primary valve incompetence of the saphenous veins, incompetence of the perforating veins, or incompetence or obstruction of the deep veins.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Fibrin cuff hypothesis: High venous pressure was found to be associated with a pericapillary infiltrate. This includes fibrin and other proteins, which are known to lead to fibrosis. It was hypothesized that these ‘cuffs’ could act as an impediment to the diffusion of oxygen and nutrients.

 

Option B. White cell trapping hypothesis: Leukocytes were found to be reduced in the blood returning from legs with venous hypertension. This decrease in leukocyte passage was shown to increase if short-term venous hypertension was induced by the application of a tourniquet. This led to the concept of white cell ‘trapping’, which, however, has not been confirmed by further investigation.

 

Option C. Tissue anoxia: Originally, it was thought that static blood within the superficial veins led to hypoxia, which caused tissue death (stasis ulcers). This was not confirmed by investigation of venous oxygen saturation, which was found to be higher in ulcerated limbs

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Ambulatory venous hypertension is the only accepted underlying cause of venous ulceration.
  • This also explains why venous ulcers are never seen in the upper limb.

choices.text: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
Autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease

questions.text: A 34-year-old female came with history of intermittent flank pain for 5 months. She had recurrent UTl. Physical examination shows bilateral, nontender upper abdominal masses. Serum urea nitrogen is 30 mg/dL and a creatinine is 1.5 mg/dL. Renal ultrasonography shows bilaterally enlarged kidneys with multiple parenchymal anechoic masses. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

 

  • The patient's presentation of intermittent flank pain, recurrent urinary tract infections, hypertension, and the presence of enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts on renal ultrasonography strongly suggests autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).
  • ADPKD is characterized by the development of numerous cysts in the kidneys, which can lead to hypertension and renal function impairment, as indicated by the elevated serum urea nitrogen and creatinine.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medullary sponge kidney typically presents with calcifications within the renal medulla, not with multiple parenchymal cysts.

 

Option B. Simple renal cysts are usually asymptomatic, single, and don't cause renal enlargement or significant kidney dysfunction.

 

Option D. Autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease (ADTKD) often presents with progressive chronic kidney disease without the presence of multiple large cysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with recurrent UTIs, hypertension, and bilateral renal masses, ADPKD should be strongly considered.
  • This is particularly suggested by ultrasound findings of enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy came to consult you in your OPD where he gave history of trauma to his right eye. On carrying out slit-lamp examination, you see a superficial injury on the cornea. Usually, in injuries involving only the corneal epithelium, the stratified squamous epithelium rapidly regenerates because of the presence of stem cells. Where are the Palisades of Vogt containing the stem cells located?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Limbus

 

  • Limbus refers to a circumcorneal transitional zone of the conjunctivocorneal & corneoscleral junction.
  • It has basal cells arranged in folds, increasing surface area for the mitotically active stem cells. This is called as Pallisades of Vogt.
  • Contains unipotent stem cells.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Retina: The retina is the light-sensitive layer that processes visual information.

 

Option C. Aqueous Humour is the clear fluid in the anterior chamber of the eye, between the cornea and the lens.

 

Option D. Cornea, while the Palisades of Vogt are closely related to the health and maintenance of the cornea, they are specifically located in the limbus, not within the cornea itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Palisades of Vogt, containing stem cells crucial for corneal regeneration and repair, are located in the limbus, the border area between the cornea and the sclera.

choices.text: Copper intrauterine device
Combination oral contraceptives (COCs)
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS)
Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNG-IUS)

questions.text: All except which of the following are appropriate medical treatments for adenomyosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Copper intrauterine device

 

  • The copper intrauterine device (IUD) is primarily a contraceptive device and does not release any hormones that could help manage adenomyosis symptoms.
  • In contrast, adenomyosis is a condition where endometrial tissue, which normally lines the uterus, exists within and grows into the muscular wall of the uterus.
  • This can lead to heavy menstrual bleeding and pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Combination oral contraceptives (COCs): These can be used to manage adenomyosis symptoms by regulating menstrual cycles, reducing menstrual flow, and alleviating associated pain.

 

Option C. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs): NSAIDs are commonly used for pain relief in adenomyosis and can help manage menstrual cramps and inflammation.

 

Option D. Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNG-IUS): This device releases a small amount of the hormone levonorgestrel into the uterus, which can help reduce heavy menstrual bleeding and pain associated with adenomyosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the management of adenomyosis, medical treatments aim to relieve symptoms such as heavy menstrual bleeding and pain.
  • Hormonal therapies like COCs and the LNG-IUS can be effective, as well as NSAIDs for pain relief.
  • The copper IUD is not typically used for adenomyosis treatment as it lacks hormonal activity that could alleviate symptoms.

choices.text: It blocks the action of acetylcholine
It interferes with the action of monoamine oxidase
It interferes with the action of carbonic anhydrase
It inhibits the action of acetylcholinesterase

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis reports to the clinic with symptoms of muscle fatigue and weakness, particularly towards the end of the day. After the administration of neostigmine, his symptoms significantly improve. What is the mechanism of action of neostigmine that accounts for the amelioration of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It inhibits the action of acetylcholinesterase

 

  • Neostigmine is an anticholinesterase medication, which means it inhibits the enzyme acetylcholinesterase.
  • This enzyme is responsible for breaking down acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction.
  • By inhibiting this enzyme, neostigmine increases the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, thereby enhancing neuromuscular transmission and alleviating muscle weakness.
  • This is particularly effective in conditions like myasthenia gravis, where there is a deficiency of acetylcholine receptors, leading to muscle weakness that improves with anticholinesterase medications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It blocks the action of acetylcholine: Blocking the action of acetylcholine would worsen muscle weakness, not improve it.

 

Option B. It interferes with the action of monoamine oxidase: Monoamine oxidase is involved in the breakdown of neurotransmitters in the brain, such as serotonin and norepinephrine, and is not related to muscle weakness or the action of neostigmine.

 

Option C. It interferes with the action of carbonic anhydrase: Carbonic anhydrase is an enzyme that helps maintain acid-base balance in the blood and is not related to the mechanism of action of neostigmine or muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neostigmine is an anticholinesterase medication that improves muscle weakness by inhibiting the breakdown of acetylcholine, thus increasing its availability at the neuromuscular junction.
  • It is used in the treatment of myasthenia gravis and to reverse the effects of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents.

choices.text: One limb is placed is common bile duct
Used for transhepatic drainage of bile
Burhenne’s technique is used for removal of residual stones
Cholangiogram is performed after bile becomes clear and patient is clinically improved

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement concerning the device shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Used for transhepatic drainage of bile

 

  • The above picture is that of a T-tube that is used in CBD exploration/choledocholithotomy for surgical removal of CBD stones.
  • The T tube is removed by the 8th-10th day, or later.
  • While a T-tube can be used for bile drainage, it is not specifically for transhepatic drainage.
  • Transhepatic drainage usually refers to percutaneous methods rather than a T-tube placed surgically.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. One limb is placed is common bile duct: Correct. The T-tube is designed with one limb to be placed in the common bile duct during surgery to ensure bile drainage and to prevent accumulation in the site of surgery.

 

Option C. Burhenne’s technique is used for removal of residual stones: Correct. Burhenne’s technique may involve the use of a mature T-tube tract for the removal of residual stones in the bile duct.

 

Option D. Cholangiogram is performed after bile becomes clear and patient is clinically improved: Correct. After placement of a T-tube, a cholangiogram can be performed to assess the bile ducts once the patient has clinically improved and the bile drainage is clear, indicating no further obstruction or leak.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When managing a patient after CBD exploration, a T-tube may be placed for bile drainage.
  • The T-tube is not used for transhepatic drainage but rather for post-surgical drainage and access for potential removal of residual stones.
  • A cholangiogram is performed after recovery to ensure clear drainage before the tube is removed.

choices.text: Somatostatin reduces Acid Secretion
Gastrin promotes Acid Secretion
Histamine Blockers reduce Acid Secretion
Secretin promotes Acid Secretion

questions.text: Which one of the following statements about gastric acid secretion is not accurate based on its impact and regulation in patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Secretin promotes Acid Secretion

 

  • Secretin does not promote acid secretion.
  • In fact, it inhibits gastric acid secretion and stimulates bicarbonate secretion.
  • Different Stimuli Affecting Gastric Acid Secretion:

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Somatostatin reduces Acid Secretion: Somatostatin reduces gastric acid secretion by inhibiting gastrin release and directly acting on parietal cells.

 

Option B. Gastrin promotes Acid Secretion: Gastrin stimulates acid secretion by directly acting on parietal cells, increasing the risk of GERD symptoms.

 

Option C. Histamine Blockers reduce Acid Secretion: Histamine blockers (H2 blockers) reduce acid secretion, helping alleviate GERD symptoms by blocking histamine action on parietal cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand the roles of different hormones and substances in the regulation of gastric acid secretion, which is crucial in the pathophysiology and management of GERD.

questions.text: A 3-year-old female child was brought by her mother to the OPD with complaints of chronic cough, skin rashes, diarrhoea, and foul-smelling stools. On Examination, the growth rate of the child is in the lower percentile limits and final diagnosis of cystic fibrosis was made. Which of the following vitamins is most likely to be deficient is this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinol

 

  • In cystic fibrosis (CF), there is impaired pancreatic enzyme function, which leads to difficulty in absorbing fat-soluble vitamins, including Vitamin A (Retinol), Vitamin D, Vitamin E, and Vitamin K.
  • Among the options given, retinol (Vitamin A) is the fat-soluble vitamin most likely to be deficient in a child with CF due to the malabsorption associated with the disease.
  • Vitamin A deficiency can contribute to the clinical picture with symptoms such as night blindness and skin issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Biotin: Biotin is a water-soluble B-vitamin, and its deficiency is less likely in CF compared to fat-soluble vitamins.

 

Option C. Folic acid: Folic acid (Vitamin B9) is also water-soluble, and while nutritional deficiencies can occur in CF, folic acid deficiency is not as directly linked to CF as the malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins.

 

Option D. Riboflavin: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) is another water-soluble vitamin, and its deficiency is less commonly associated with CF than that of fat-soluble vitamins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Children with cystic fibrosis often experience malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins due to pancreatic insufficiency, making deficiencies in vitamins such as Vitamin A (retinol) more common and significant in this population.
  • Management of CF includes supplementation of these vitamins to prevent associated deficiencies.

questions.text: Which antiepileptic drug is known to cause gum hypertrophy as a side effect at therapeutic doses?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phenytoin

 

  • Gum hypertrophy, also known as gingival hyperplasia, is a well-known adverse effect of phenytoin, an antiepileptic drug.
  • This side effect can occur even when phenytoin is used within therapeutic levels.
  • Good oral hygiene can help to minimize the risk, but in some cases, the severity of gum hypertrophy may necessitate a change in medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenobarbitone: Another antiepileptic drug, but it is not commonly associated with gum hypertrophy as a side effect.

 

Option C. Carbamazepine: While carbamazepine is another antiepileptic drug, it does not typically cause gum hypertrophy.

 

Option D. Sodium valproate: There seems to be a typo in the option; it should probably read "Sodium valproate," which is also an antiepileptic drug. Like the others listed, it does not commonly cause gum hypertrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Phenytoin is associated with the adverse effect of gum hypertrophy, even when used within therapeutic levels, distinguishing it from other antiepileptic drugs such as phenobarbitone, carbamazepine, and sodium valproate.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida is in active labor at 41 weeks. The cardiotocograph (CTG) shows the following trace at 6 cm cervical dilatation. This indicates:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fetal Hypoxia

 

  • The CTG shows decelerations that could be indicative of fetal hypoxia, particularly if they are late decelerations that occur after the peak of contractions and are associated with uterine contractions.
  • Fetal hypoxia occurs when there is a compromise in the oxygen delivery to the fetus, and it can be recognized on a CTG by consistent late decelerations. It is an ominous sign

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cord Compression: Usually presents as variable decelerations which are abrupt decreases in fetal heart rate that can occur at any time during contractions and have an erratic appearance on the CTG.

 

Option C. Head Compression: Typically presents as early decelerations where the fetal heart rate decreases at the beginning of a contraction and returns to baseline as the contraction ends, mirroring the contraction.

 

Option D. Cord Prolapse: An obstetric emergency that would likely cause sudden, severe, and sustained bradycardia, not necessarily the pattern of decelerations associated with fetal hypoxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • On a cardiotocograph (CTG), fetal hypoxia is often indicated by late decelerations—repetitive or persistent decelerations beginning after the peak of a contraction and returning to the baseline only after the contraction has finished.

choices.text: Increased specificity due to two rounds of amplification with different primer sets
Reduced need for template DNA
Elimination of the need for thermal cycling

questions.text: A microbiology researcher is developing a diagnostic test for a rare, but highly infectious bacterial pathogen that has been identified in a recent outbreak. The pathogen is known to be present in extremely low quantities in patient samples and shares close genetic similarities with a range of commensal bacteria normally found in the human microbiota. To ensure the test is highly specific to the pathogen, the researcher decides to employ a variation of PCR technology. Which of the following is the primary advantage of the method the researcher is most likely considering over traditional PCR methods?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased specificity due to two rounds of amplification with different primer sets

 

  • Nested PCR, which the researcher is most likely considering, involves two rounds of PCR amplification.
  • The first round uses one set of primers, and the product of this reaction serves as the template for the second round, which uses a different set of primers that are internal to the first set.
  • This approach greatly increases the specificity of the PCR, making it particularly useful for detecting pathogens that are present in very low quantities and closely resemble other organisms genetically.
  • The use of two sets of primers to amplify different regions of the target DNA sequence allows for a more precise identification of the pathogen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decreased time for amplification: Incorrect, because nested PCR actually requires more time due to the two rounds of amplification.

 

Option C. Reduced need for template DNA: Incorrect, the need for template DNA does not significantly change with nested PCR. Both traditional and nested PCR require an adequate amount of template DNA for successful amplification.

 

Option D. Elimination of the need for thermal cycling: Incorrect, nested PCR, like traditional PCR, still requires thermal cycling for DNA denaturation, primer annealing, and extension steps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nested PCR enhances the specificity of DNA amplification by using two sets of primers in two successive PCR reactions, thereby reducing the likelihood of non-specific amplification.

choices.text: The prior probability of SLE in the patient, along with the sensitivity and specificity of each test
The incidence rate of SLE in the population and the predictive value of each test
The incidence and prevalence rates of SLE in the general population
The relative risk of SLE in this patient compared to the general population

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the rheumatology clinic with symptoms suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), including a malar rash, joint pain, and fatigue. Given the clinical suspicion, you order a panel of 6 diagnostic tests for SLE, of which 4 return positive and 2 are negative. To accurately determine the current probability of SLE in this patient based on these test results, which of the following sets of information is most essential?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The prior probability of SLE in the patient, along with the sensitivity and specificity of each test

 

  • To refine the probability of SLE after obtaining test results, it's essential to know the prior probability of the disease (often based on clinical judgment and prevalence in similar patients) and the sensitivity and specificity of each test.
  • This information allows for the application of Bayes' theorem, which updates the probability of a disease based on how well the test performs and the pre-test probability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The incidence rate of SLE in the population and the predictive value of each test: While the incidence of SLE and the predictive values of the tests can offer some insights, they are not as directly applicable to revising an individual patient's probability of disease as the combination of prior probability with sensitivity and specificity.

 

Option C. The incidence and prevalence rates of SLE in the general population: Incidence and prevalence provide a population-wide view but do not offer the individualized probability adjustment provided by knowing the specific tests' performance characteristics and the patient's initial likelihood of disease.

 

Option D. The relative risk of SLE in this patient compared to the general population: Relative risk is a measure used in cohort studies to compare the risk in an exposed group to a non-exposed group and is less relevant in the clinical scenario of diagnosing an individual patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Baye’s Theorem: Gives relationship between PPV of a screening test and Sensitivity, Specificity & Prevalence of disease in a population

 

 

 

  • Actual Baye’s Theorem: Gives relationship between Posttest probability of a disease in a population (PTP = PPV) and Sensitivity, Specificity & Post-test probability of a disease in a population (pTP = Prevalence)

questions.text: Biopsy of a small, rounded rectal polyp demonstrates glands and sawtooth crypts composed of a proliferation of goblet and columnar epithelial cells. No atypia is seen. This polyp is best classified as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperplastic polyp

 

  • The description of a small, rounded rectal polyp with glands and sawtooth crypts composed of a proliferation of goblet and columnar epithelial cells, without any atypia, is characteristic of a hyperplastic polyp.
  • Hyperplastic polyps are the most common type of polyps found in the colon and are considered non-neoplastic.
  • The sawtooth appearance of the crypts is a hallmark feature of hyperplastic polyps.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Peutz-Jeghers polyp: Peutz-Jeghers polyps are hamartomatous polyps associated with the Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. These polyps are characterized by a distinctive arborizing (tree-branching) pattern of smooth muscle extending into the polyp, which is not described here.

 

Option C. Tubular adenoma: Tubular adenomas are neoplastic polyps that show dysplastic epithelial cells forming tubular structures. They can have a risk of progression to colorectal cancer, unlike hyperplastic polyps.

 

Option D. Tubulovillous adenoma: Tubulovillous adenomas are a type of adenoma that contains both tubular and villous architectural patterns. Like tubular adenomas, they show dysplasia and have a potential for malignant transformation, which is not indicated in the described polyp.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hyperplastic polyps are characterized by the proliferation of goblet and columnar epithelial cells with a sawtooth appearance of crypts and are considered non-neoplastic.
  • The absence of dysplasia differentiates them from adenomatous polyps, such as tubular and tubulovillous adenomas.

questions.text: Disodium cromoglycate is used by which of the following routes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhalation route

 

  • Disodium cromoglycate (also known as cromolyn sodium) is primarily used by inhalation for the prophylactic treatment of asthma.
  • It acts as a mast cell stabilizer, preventing the release of histamine and other mediators involved in asthma's inflammatory process.
  • It is not a bronchodilator and is used to prevent allergic reactions that can trigger asthma attacks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oral route: While disodium cromoglycate can be taken orally for certain conditions like food allergies and mastocytosis, its primary use for asthma is via inhalation.

 

Option C. Intravenous route: It is not commonly administered intravenously for asthma treatment.

 

Option D. Intramuscular route: Intramuscular administration is not a standard route for disodium cromoglycate in treating asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disodium cromoglycate is used by inhalation as a prophylactic treatment in asthma management.
  • It works by stabilizing mast cells, thus preventing the release of inflammatory mediators that contribute to asthma symptoms.

questions.text: The co-factor for glutathione peroxidase is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Selenium

 

  • Selenium acts as a co-factor for the enzyme glutathione peroxidase, which plays a critical role in protecting the body from oxidative damage by reducing lipid hydroperoxides to their corresponding alcohols and reducing free hydrogen peroxide to water.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Manganese: It is a co-factor for different enzymes including manganese superoxide dismutase, but not for glutathione peroxidase.

 

Option C. Copper: It serves as a co-factor for enzymes like cytochrome c oxidase and ceruloplasmin, but not glutathione peroxidase.

 

Option D. Zinc: This element is a co-factor for over 300 enzymes including alcohol dehydrogenase and carbonic anhydrase, but it is not directly involved with glutathione peroxidase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Selenium, specifically, is integral to the antioxidant function of glutathione peroxidase, highlighting the importance of micronutrients in maintaining cellular health and preventing oxidative damage.

questions.text: A hospital is evaluating various sterilization methods to update their infection control protocols, particularly for temperature-sensitive medical equipment. One of the technologies under consideration is the STERRAD gas plasma system. The committee reviewing the options is focused on understanding the active sterilizing agent used in this system, given its compatibility with a wide range of medical devices and its effectiveness in sterilization. Which of the following is the active agent used in STERRAD gas plasma sterilizers?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) H2O2 (Hydrogen Peroxide)

 

  • STERRAD gas plasma sterilizers use hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as the active sterilizing agent.
  • The system works by first vaporizing the hydrogen peroxide and then using radio frequency energy to convert it into a plasma state.
  • This process generates free radicals that effectively destroy microorganisms, providing a high level of sterilization.
  • The use of H2O2 and its conversion into a plasma state allow for effective sterilization at lower temperatures, making it suitable for temperature-sensitive and delicate medical equipment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. N2O (Nitrous Oxide): Incorrect, N2O is not used as a sterilizing agent in STERRAD systems.

 

Option C. Ozone: Incorrect, ozone is used in some sterilization processes but is not the active agent in STERRAD gas plasma sterilizers.

 

Option D. EtO (Ethylene Oxide): Incorrect, while EtO is a common sterilizing agent, particularly for heat-sensitive materials, it is not used in STERRAD systems. EtO sterilization typically requires aeration post-processing to remove residual gas, unlike STERRAD which does not leave such residues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The active agent used in STERRAD gas plasma sterilizers is hydrogen peroxide (H2O2).
  • This technology is effective for sterilizing a wide range of medical devices, especially those that are sensitive to temperature, due to its low-temperature operation.

choices.text: Closed reduction with cylinder cast
Open reduction with screw fixation of the fragments
Blind fixation of the two fragments with Kirschner-wire
Open reduction with Kirschner-wire fixation of the fragment with tension band wiring

questions.text: Transverse fracture of the patella with separation of fragments is best treated by:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Open reduction with Kirschner-wire fixation of the fragment with tension band wiring

 

  • Open reduction with Kirschner-wire fixation and tension band wiring is a commonly recommended treatment for transverse fractures of the patella with separation of fragments.
  • This method allows for precise realignment of the bone fragments and stabilization of the fracture, promoting proper healing and restoring knee function.
  • The tension band wiring technique converts tensile forces into compression forces at the fracture site, which is beneficial for fracture healing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Closed reduction with cylinder cast: This method might be considered for non-displaced or minimally displaced fractures but is not ideal for transverse fractures with significant fragment separation.

 

Option B. Open reduction with screw fixation of the fragments: Screw fixation can be used for certain types of patellar fractures, but tension band wiring with Kirschner-wires is more commonly recommended for transverse fractures.

 

Option C. Blind fixation of the two fragments with Kirschner-wire: Blind fixation without direct visualization of the fracture (open reduction) may not ensure proper alignment of the fracture fragments and can lead to improper healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For transverse fractures of the patella with significant separation of fragments, open reduction with Kirschner-wire fixation combined with tension band wiring is considered an effective treatment.

choices.text: Its origin lies above the tip of greater cornu of hyoid bone
Its course is divided into 3 parts by mylohyoid muscle
Second part of the artery has a sublingual course
It terminates by anastomosing with the artery of the opposite side

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about the structure pointed in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It terminates by anastomosing with the artery of the opposite side

 

  • The pointed structure is Lingual artery.
  • It terminates by anastomosing with the artery of the opposite side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Its origin lies above the tip of greater cornu of hyoid bone: False. It arises from external carotid artery opposite the tip of greater cornu of hyoid bone

 

Option B. Its course is divided into 3 parts by mylohyoid muscle: False. Its course is divided into 3 parts by Hyoglossus muscle.

 

Option C. Second part of the artery has a sublingual course: False. The third part of the artery runs beneath the mucus membrane of the under surface of the tongue on each side of frenulum linguae.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Lingual artery is the only branch from external carotid artery to have such a termination by anastomosing with the similar artery of the opposite side at the tip of tongue.

choices.text: Diffuse large B cell Lymphoma
B cell rich T cell lymphoma
Mediastinal rich B cell lymphoma
T cell Lymphoblastic/Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia

questions.text: A young boy came with dyspnea and was found to have a mediastinal mass. Which of the following is known to produce mediastinal lymphadenopathy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) T cell Lymphoblastic/Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia

 

  • T-cell lymphoblastic lymphoma/acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL/LBL) is known for its association with mediastinal masses, especially in children and young adults.
  • The thymus, located in the anterior mediastinum, is often involved, leading to significant mediastinal lymphadenopathy.
  • This condition presents with symptoms like dyspnea, cough, and superior vena cava syndrome due to the mass effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diffuse large B cell Lymphoma: While it can involve the mediastinum, it is more commonly associated with lymphadenopathy in other regions.

 

Option B. B cell rich T cell lymphoma: This is not a standard classification of lymphomas, and T-cell lymphomas typically, but not exclusively, involve the mediastinum.

 

Option C.  Mediastinal rich B cell lymphoma: While primary mediastinal (thymic) large B-cell lymphoma is a distinct entity that presents with a mediastinal mass, T-cell lymphoblastic lymphoma/ALL is more characteristically associated with mediastinal lymphadenopathy in younger patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • T-cell lymphoblastic lymphoma/acute lymphoblastic leukemia is commonly associated with the presence of a mediastinal mass and mediastinal lymphadenopathy in young patients, often leading to symptoms such as dyspnea due to the mass effect on the surrounding structures.

questions.text: A public health officer is analyzing the annual health report for a small town with a population of 20,000. The report includes data on births and infant mortality to assess the town's healthcare needs and the effectiveness of maternal and child health services. Over the past year, the town recorded 456 births, of which 56 were stillbirths. There were 247 total deaths, with 56 occurring within the first 28 days of life and an additional 34 infant deaths before reaching their first birthday. Based on this data, what is the Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) per 1000 live births in this town?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 225

 

  • The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is calculated by dividing the total number of infant deaths (within the first year of life) by the total number of live births in the same period, then multiplying by 1000.
  • In this case, the total number of infant deaths is 90 (56 in the first 28 days + 34 between 28 days and before the first birthday).
  • The number of live births is 400 (456 total births - 56 stillbirths).
  • Thus, the IMR is (90/400) x 1000 = 225.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IMR = Infant deaths/Live births × 1000

questions.text:
A 28-year-old female visits her family physician for a routine health check-up. During the consultation, she inquires about Human Papillomavirus (HPV) after a friend was recently diagnosed with an HPV-related condition. The patient is particularly interested in understanding the various health issues HPV can cause, as she has not been vaccinated against it. The physician explains the broad spectrum of diseases associated with HPV infection, emphasizing its role in both benign and malignant conditions. Which of the following health issues can be caused by HPV infection?

 

 

  1. Cervical cancer
  2. Anal cancer
  3. Oropharyngeal cancer
  4. Laryngeal papillomatosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, and 4

 

  • HPV is a group of viruses that are associated with several types of cancers as well as benign conditions:
    1. Cervical cancer: High-risk HPV types, particularly types 16 and 18, are the primary cause of cervical cancer.
    2. Anal cancer: HPV infection is also linked to the development of anal cancer, with high-risk HPV types being significant contributors.
    3. Oropharyngeal cancer: Certain HPV types, especially HPV 16, have been identified as risk factors for oropharyngeal cancer.
    4. Laryngeal papillomatosis: This condition, characterized by the growth of noncancerous tumors in the airways, is caused by HPV, particularly types 6 and 11.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPV-related Cancers:

 

  •  
  • Cervical cancer (HPV 16,18)
  • Oropharyngeal cancers (HPV 16)
  • Genital warts (HPV 6,11)
  • Laryngeal papillomatosis (HPV 6,11)
  • Anal cancer
  • Penile cancer
  • Vaginal cancer
  • Vulvar cancer

questions.text:
A 32-year-old female presents to the emergency department after being bitten on the leg by a raccoon in a suburban park. The animal was not captured, and its rabies vaccination status is unknown. The wound is cleansed, and tetanus prophylaxis is updated. The patient is anxious about rabies and inquires about the necessary steps to prevent the disease. The attending physician considers the administration of Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIg) as part of the post-exposure prophylaxis. Regarding the use of RIg in this scenario, which of the following statements are correct?

 

 

  1. RIg is contraindicated if more than 72 hours have passed since the exposure.
  2. The deltoid muscle is the preferred site for the maximum dose administration of RIg.
  3. The recommended RIg dose is 20 IU/kg body weight.
  4. Equine RIg can be used as an alternative if human RIg is unavailable.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 & 4

 

  • Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIg) is recommended as part of post-exposure prophylaxis for rabies, particularly in unvaccinated individuals or when the rabies status of the biting animal is unknown.
  • The appropriate dose of RIg is 20 IU/kg body weight, and it should be administered as soon as possible after exposure.
  • If human RIg is unavailable, equine RIg can be considered as an alternative, with careful monitoring for potential allergic reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

  1. RIg is contraindicated if more than 72 hours have passed since the exposure: While immediate administration of RIg is ideal, it is not contraindicated if given more than 72 hours after exposure, especially if the rabies vaccine series has not been completed.
  2. The deltoid muscle is the preferred site for the maximum dose administration of RIg: The preferred site for RIg administration is not the deltoid muscle but rather infiltrating around and into the wound. Any remaining volume should be given intramuscularly at a site distant from the vaccine administration site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rabies Immunoglobulin:

 

  •  
  • Dose of Human Rabies Immunoglobulin (HRIg): 20 IU/kg body weight
  • Dose of Equine Rabies Immunoglobulin (ERIg): 40 IU/kg body weight
  • RIg must be given as soon as possible.
  • RIg is NOT recommended beyond the 7th day of starting first dose of vaccine.
  • RIg must never be given intravenously.
  • Entire dose of RIg (or as much as possible) must be infiltrated around the wound(s) site(s).
  • Remaining dose, if any, must be given intramuscularly in deltoid.

choices.text: The skin discoloration represents a benign and temporary condition
The change in skin colour indicates an urgent need to discontinue phototherapy
This skin pigmentation change requires immediate cessation of phototherapy and initiation of exchange transfusion
The discoloration is indicative of a rare but severe allergic reaction to phototherapy

questions.text: A full-term neonate weighing 3 kg presents with jaundice on the third day of life, starting from the sclera and progressing to the trunk. By the fifth day, total bilirubin has reached 11 mg/dL. The infant undergoes phototherapy, after which a dark, grayish-brown skin discoloration is observed. Which statement regarding this new finding is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The skin discoloration represents a benign and temporary condition

 

  • The skin discoloration represents a benign and temporary condition known as "bronze baby syndrome."
  • This condition can occur when a neonate with elevated bilirubin levels undergoes phototherapy, particularly if there is concurrent cholestasis.
  • The dark, grayish-brown discoloration is due to the photo-oxidation of bilirubin and is generally harmless, resolving on its own after the phototherapy is stopped or the underlying hyperbilirubinemia is treated.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. The change in skin colour indicates an urgent need to discontinue phototherapy: The change in skin colour indicating an urgent need to discontinue phototherapy is not correct. While changes in skin colour should be monitored, bronze baby syndrome does not necessitate the cessation of phototherapy unless there are other underlying conditions that warrant it.

 

Option C. This skin pigmentation change requires immediate cessation of phototherapy and initiation of exchange transfusion: The suggestion that this skin pigmentation change requires immediate cessation of phototherapy and the initiation of exchange transfusion is also incorrect. Exchange transfusion is a treatment for severe hyperbilirubinemia when there is a risk of kernicterus, not for the skin discoloration associated with bronze baby syndrome.

 

Option D. The discoloration is indicative of a rare but severe allergic reaction to phototherapy: The discoloration being indicative of a rare but severe allergic reaction to phototherapy is an incorrect statement. Bronze baby syndrome is not an allergic reaction but rather a known side effect of phototherapy in certain infants, particularly those with liver involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bronze baby syndrome is a temporary and benign skin discoloration that occurs in some neonates receiving phototherapy for jaundice, especially in the presence of cholestasis.
  • It does not require stopping phototherapy or initiating exchange transfusion unless indicated by the severity of hyperbilirubinemia and risk of kernicterus.

questions.text: A patient present with ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis, enophthalmos and absence of the ciliospinal reflex. Considering these clinical findings, which surgical intervention would be most appropriate for correcting the ptosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Müller muscle-conjunctival resection

 

  • This procedure targets the Müller muscle and is typically used for milder forms of ptosis, which is seen in the case of Horner's syndrome-related ptosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Frontalis sling operation: This procedure is often the treatment of choice for severe ptosis with poor levator function, as it can provide the necessary lift by connecting the eyelid to the frontalis muscle.

 

Option C. Tarsorrhaphy: Partially sewing the eyelids together can provide mechanical elevation but is typically reserved for cases where corneal protection is needed and not for ptosis correction.

 

Option D. Blepharoplasty: This is a cosmetic procedure that removes excess skin, muscle, or fat from the eyelids and may not adequately address the ptosis in Horner's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Muller’s muscle-conjunctival resection (MMCR) is the surgical treatment of choice for mild ptosis, such as that found in Horner's syndrome, where there is good levator function.
  • This approach is useful for patients presenting with mild ptosis and excellent levator function or ptosis secondary to Horner’s syndrome and anophthalmic socket.
  • It is a modification of the Fasanella-Servat procedure where a bit of tarsus is removed along with conjunctiva and muller’s muscle.

questions.text: Conditions which are contraindicated for vacuum extractions are all, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Occipito-posterior position

 

  • Vacuum extraction is a method used to assist the delivery of a baby using a vacuum device.
  • It is not contraindicated in occipito-posterior positions, and in fact, it can sometimes be used to assist delivery in such cases, although careful consideration and expertise are required due to the increased risk of complications compared to occipito-anterior positions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Face presentation: Vacuum extraction is contraindicated in face presentations due to the risk of injury to the facial structures and the difficulty in achieving a secure and safe application of the vacuum device.

 

Option B. Extreme prematurity: The use of vacuum extraction in extremely premature infants is contraindicated due to their fragile cranial structures and the increased risk of intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Fetal coagulopathies: In conditions where the fetus has a known coagulopathy, the use of vacuum extraction is contraindicated due to the increased risk of causing cranial bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While vacuum extraction is contraindicated in face presentations, extreme prematurity, and fetal coagulopathies due to the increased risk of injury, it is not typically contraindicated in occipito-posterior positions, although it may present more challenges and risks than in occipito-anterior positions.

choices.text: Continuous oxygen at 2 L/min

questions.text: A 69-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) has been admitted to the hospital three times over the last year for COPD exacerbations with current Spo2 of 91% on room air. PFT shows FEV1 of 45% predicted. Which of the following treatments is most likely to decrease the frequency of his exacerbations?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Daily azithromycin 500mg

 

  • Azithromycin has anti-inflammatory and immunomodulating effects, which have been shown to reduce the frequency of COPD exacerbations.
  • It is especially useful in patients with severe COPD, characterized by an FEV1 < 50% of predicted, who have frequent exacerbations despite optimized therapy with bronchodilators and inhaled steroids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Continuous oxygen at 2 L/min: Continuous oxygen therapy is indicated for COPD patients with chronic respiratory failure (resting Spo2 ≤ 88%). While it improves survival, its role specifically in decreasing the frequency of exacerbations is less clear.

 

Option C. Nocturnal BIPAP machine: Nocturnal BIPAP is indicated in COPD patients with chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure not attributable to other causes (such as obstructive sleep apnea), rather than for reducing exacerbation frequency.

 

Option D. IV steroids are used to treat acute exacerbations of COPD but are not indicated as a preventive measure for reducing the frequency of exacerbations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For patients with severe COPD who have frequent exacerbations, the addition of daily azithromycin can reduce the frequency of exacerbations.
  • However, it should be noted that long-term use can be associated with increased resistance to macrolides, hearing loss, and cardiovascular risks.
  • Therefore, it should be used after evaluating the risks and benefits for the individual patient.

choices.text: Otitis media

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to a pediatric clinic by his parents due to a high fever, cough, and a rash that started on his face and then spread to the rest of his body. The parents report that the child had been exposed to a classmate with a similar illness a week ago. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes conjunctivitis and small white spots inside the child's mouth. The child has not been vaccinated against common childhood diseases. Considering the child's symptoms and history, the pediatrician is concerned about potential complications associated with the suspected diagnosis. Which of the following is the 'Least common' complication associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE)

 

  • The child's presentation is consistent with measles, indicated by the fever, cough, rash, conjunctivitis, and Koplik spots.
  • While measles can lead to several complications, Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare but fatal long-term complication of measles, occurring months to years after the acute illness.
  • SSPE is characterized by a gradual deterioration of cognitive function, behavior, and motor skills.
  • Sub-acute sclerosing pan-encephalitis (SSPE):
  • Also known as ‘Dawson’s disease’, ‘Dawson’s encephalitis’.
  • Rare complication of Measles developing 7 – 10 years after Measles infection (Fatality 10–20%).
  • Characterised by progressive mental deterioration leading to paralysis (persisting virus in brain).
  • Frequency: 1 per 10,000–100,000 cases of natural Measles

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diarrhea is a common acute complication of measles, particularly in young children.

 

Option B. Pneumonia is one of the most common serious complications of measles, contributing significantly to the morbidity and mortality associated with the disease.

 

Option C. Otitis media is a common complication in children with measles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Common complications of Measles:
    • Diarrhoea
    • Pneumonia and other respiratory complications
    • Otitis media: MC complication of Measles in children
  • Serious complications of Measles:
    • Febrile convulsions
    • Encephalitis
    • Sub-acute sclerosing pan-encephalitis (SSPE)
  •

choices.text: Analgesia and antibiotics
Cold compress
Shift to OT for evacuation

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman P1L1 delivered 1 hour back. She complains of severe perineal pain and is unable to pass urine. On examination, you note the following. Her PR is 110/min and BP is 90/60mmHg. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Shift to OT for evacuation

 

  • Given the significant perineal pain, inability to pass urine, and the hypotensive and tachycardic vital signs, this scenario is suggestive of postpartum hemorrhage with possible hematoma formation, which is an emergency.
  • Immediate evacuation of a suspected hematoma in the operating theater (OT) is critical to prevent further blood loss, control bleeding, and stabilize the patient.
  • While catheterization is important for assessing urinary output, the provided vital signs and severe pain point towards a more acute issue that necessitates surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Analgesia and antibiotics: Pain management is essential, but this does not address the underlying cause of hypotension and tachycardia.

 

Option B. Catheterization: It's a standard procedure postpartum but given the urgency of the symptoms, it may be a temporizing measure before definitive surgical management.

 

Option C. Cold compress: May help with pain relief but is not the priority given the potential for ongoing hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When faced with a postpartum patient who has severe pain, is hypotensive, and tachycardic, the possibility of a hematoma or hemorrhage should be considered and managed emergently.
  • This often requires prompt surgical exploration and evacuation of the hematoma, along with resuscitation and stabilization of the patient.

questions.text: Forced alkaline diuresis is effective in management of poisoning by which of the following agents?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phenobarbitone

 

  • Forced alkaline diuresis is effective in enhancing the excretion of weakly acidic drugs like phenobarbitone by increasing the pH of the urine.
  • This process traps the drug in its ionized form in the renal tubules, preventing reabsorption and promoting elimination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lead: Chelation therapy, not alkaline diuresis, is the mainstay of treatment for lead poisoning.

 

Option C. Iron: Iron poisoning is typically managed with chelation therapy using agents such as deferoxamine.

 

Option D. Organophosphates: Treatment of organophosphate poisoning involves the use of atropine and pralidoxime, and not forced diuresis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Forced alkaline diuresis is utilized to enhance the elimination of certain drugs from the body, such as weak acids like phenobarbitone, by increasing urine pH and trapping the drug in an ionized state in the urine, promoting its excretion.

choices.text: Test dose of drugs

questions.text: A nurse in a primary care clinic is observed administering an intramuscular injection to a child. Considering standard medical practice, which of the following substances is the nurse most likely administering?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tetanus toxoid

 

  • This vaccine, given for prophylaxis against tetanus, is commonly administered intramuscularly as part of routine immunization schedules or wound management.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Test dose of drugs: Test doses are used to assess allergic reactions or sensitivity to certain medications. They are often given intramuscularly if the drug is known to cause sensitivity reactions.

 

Option C. BCG vaccine: The BCG vaccine, used against tuberculosis, is usually given intradermally, not intramuscularly, typically in the upper arm.

 

Option D. Low molecular weight heparin: Often used for anticoagulation, low molecular weight heparin is typically administered subcutaneously, not intramuscularly, to prevent deep vein thrombosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The tetanus toxoid vaccine is commonly administered via intramuscular injection for the prevention of tetanus.
  • Other options, like the BCG vaccine and low molecular weight heparin, have different recommended routes of administration (intradermal and subcutaneous, respectively).

questions.text: A 25-year-old man undergoes a lengthy operative procedure under general anesthesia. Postoperatively, he is observed to have green-coloured urine in his catheter bag. Which of the following anesthetic agents is known to cause this unusual urine discoloration?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Propofol

 

  • This intravenous anesthetic agent can cause a benign greenish discoloration of the urine when used over prolonged periods or in higher doses due to its phenolic metabolites.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Sevoflurane: While commonly used as an inhaled anesthetic, it does not typically cause changes in urine colour.

 

Option C. Ketamine: Known for its dissociative anesthetic properties, ketamine does not typically result in green urine.

 

Option D. Halothane: An older inhaled anesthetic that is rarely used today, halothane is not associated with green urine discoloration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The benign green urine discoloration is associated with propofol use.

questions.text: The drug of choice to reduce perinatal transmission in Hepatitis B in pregnant women with high viral load is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tenofovir

 

  • Tenofovir is recommended as the drug of choice to reduce perinatal transmission of hepatitis B in pregnant women with high viral load.
  • It is an antiviral drug that is effective in reducing the hepatitis B viral load and is considered safe for use during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adefovir: It is an antiviral medication used to treat hepatitis B, but it is not the first choice for reducing perinatal transmission due to its safety profile in pregnancy and its potency compared to tenofovir.

 

Option B. Lamivudine: While lamivudine can be used in pregnancy, tenofovir is often preferred due to a more favourable resistance profile.

 

Option C. Telbivudine: This is also an option for treatment, but tenofovir is preferred for its efficacy and safety profile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the management of hepatitis B during pregnancy, tenofovir is considered the drug of choice to reduce perinatal transmission, especially in women with high viral loads.
  • It has a good safety profile and is effective in reducing viral replication.

choices.text: This is a case of anterior dislocation of temporomandibular joint
Temporomandibular joint is a bicondylar type of synovial joint
Contraction of medial pterygoid depresses the mandible
Sphenomandibular ligament is situated medial to temporomandibular joint

questions.text: A student after a heavy lunch from the hostel got ready for his afternoon class. He sat on the first bench and began to take notes. After a while, he yawned widely. To his surprise sadly, he could not close his mouth. The jaw was stuck. Which of the following statement is not true in the above scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Contraction of medial pterygoid depresses the mandible

 

  • The statement "Contraction of medial pterygoid depresses the mandible" is not true.
  • The primary action of the medial pterygoid muscle is to elevate the mandible (closing the jaw) and assist in protrusion (moving the lower jaw forward).
  • It does not depress the mandible.
  • The muscles responsible for depressing the mandible (opening the jaw) include the lateral pterygoid, digastric, mylohyoid, and geniohyoid muscles.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. This is a case of anterior dislocation of temporomandibular joint: True, the scenario described is consistent with an anterior dislocation of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ), where the condylar process of the mandible moves too far anteriorly and gets stuck in front of the articular eminence.

 

 

 

Option B. Temporomandibular joint is a bicondylar type of synovial joint: True, the TMJ is a bicondylar synovial joint involving the mandibular condyles and the temporal bone.

 

Option D. Sphenomandibular ligament is situated medial to temporomandibular joint: True, the sphenomandibular ligament is located medially with respect to the TMJ and provides medial support to the joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the context of TMJ anatomy and function, it's essential to recognize that the medial pterygoid muscle elevates the mandible, not depresses it.
  • An anterior dislocation of the TMJ can occur with excessive mouth opening, leading to the inability to close the mouth, as described in the scenario.

choices.text: Start high-dose nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
Perform joint fluid analysis for crystals and culture
Prescribe antibiotics for presumed septic arthritis

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with acute onset of severe pain and swelling in his left knee. He denies any recent injury but has a history of hypertension and chronic renal failure. On examination, the knee is warm, swollen, and tender, with limited range of motion. Aspiration of the knee joint yields a yellow, cloudy fluid with a high white blood cell count. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perform joint fluid analysis for crystals and culture

 

  • Joint fluid analysis is crucial in differentiating between inflammatory arthritides like gout or pseudogout and septic arthritis, especially when the presentation includes acute monoarthritis with significant effusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start high-dose nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs): High-dose NSAIDs may be used for gout but should not be initiated before excluding septic arthritis, which requires antibiotics.
 

Option B. Initiate oral glucocorticoids: Oral glucocorticoids could be considered for gout or pseudogout but, again, not before excluding infection.
 

Option D. Prescribe antibiotics for presumed septic arthritis: Prescribing antibiotics empirically for presumed septic arthritis may be appropriate in certain clinical contexts, but it is essential first to confirm the diagnosis with joint fluid analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most appropriate next step is to initiate empirical antibiotic treatment and send the aspirated fluid for culture and sensitivity, as the presentation suggests septic arthritis, characterized by acute severe pain, swelling, warmth, and a high white cell count in the joint fluid.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the graph presented?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypnogram

 

  • The image represents Hypnogram.
  • A hypnogram is a graphical depiction of the sleep cycle, recording the stages of sleep an individual goes through during the night.
  • It demonstrates the depth and quality of sleep, transitions between different sleep stages, including REM (rapid eye movement) and non-REM sleep, as well as any awakenings that occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Electroencephalogram (EEG): This test records the electrical activity of the brain over a short period of time, usually 20-40 minutes, as waveforms (alpha, beta, theta, delta) of varying frequency and amplitude. It would not typically be presented as a hypnogram.

 

 

Option C. Polysomnogram: This is a comprehensive recording of the biophysiological changes that occur during sleep. It usually includes an EEG but also records eye movement, muscle activity, and heart rhythm. While a hypnogram is a visual representation of the sleep stages derived from a polysomnogram, it's not the same thing.

 

 

 

Option D. Epworth Sleepiness Scale: This is a questionnaire used to assess daytime sleepiness, not a chart or a graph. It asks individuals to rate their likelihood of falling asleep in various situations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A hypnogram is a form of graph that represents the stages of sleep as they cycle through the night, typically recorded during a sleep study.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with persistent diarrhea, abdominal pain, and a recent unintended weight loss. A colonoscopy was performed, revealing several flask-shaped ulcers in the sigmoid colon. Histopathological examination of the biopsy specimens from these ulcers confirms the diagnosis. Based on these findings, the gastroenterologist is determining the most appropriate treatment plan. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intravenous metronidazole

 

  • The presence of flask-shaped ulcers in the sigmoid colon is highly suggestive of an infection with Entamoeba histolytica, a protozoan parasite that causes amebiasis.
  • This condition can lead to amebic colitis and, in severe cases, can progress to amebic liver abscess.
  • The treatment of choice for invasive amebiasis, such as amebic colitis, is metronidazole, which is effective against the trophozoites of Entamoeba histolytica.
  • Intravenous administration may be indicated in severe cases or when the patient is unable to take oral medications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous ceftriaxone: Incorrect, as ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum cephalosporin antibiotic primarily used for bacterial infections and would not be effective against protozoan parasites like Entamoeba histolytica.

 

Option C. Intravenous steroids and sulfasalazine: Incorrect, these are treatments typically used for inflammatory bowel diseases like ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease, not for infections caused by Entamoeba histolytica.

 

Option D. Hydrocortisone enemas: Incorrect, hydrocortisone enemas are used to treat inflammation in the lower colon, particularly in inflammatory bowel diseases, and would not be appropriate for treating an amebic infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of flask-shaped ulcers in the colon is indicative of amebic colitis, caused by the protozoan Entamoeba histolytica.
  • The most appropriate initial treatment for invasive amebiasis, including amebic colitis, is metronidazole.
  • Recognizing the clinical and histopathological features of amebic colitis is crucial for initiating the correct treatment and preventing complications such as amebic liver abscess.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is evaluated for a combination of neurologic and auditory symptoms. She exhibits polyneuropathy, sensorineural deafness, and cerebellar ataxia. Upon fundoscopic examination, distinctive retinal changes are noted. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated levels of phytanic acid. Which diagnosis best fits this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Refsum’s disease

 

  • This is characterized by a defect in phytanic acid metabolism, leading to its accumulation.
  • Patients typically present with a combination of neurologic, auditory, and visual symptoms, including retinitis pigmentosa, which aligns with the patient's clinical picture.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease: A hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy, often presenting with muscle weakness and atrophy, foot deformities, and sensory loss. It is not typically associated with hearing loss or elevated phytanic acid.

 

Option C. Kearns-Sayre syndrome: A mitochondrial disorder presenting with external ophthalmoplegia, pigmentary retinopathy, and cardiac conduction defects. It does not typically cause elevated phytanic acid levels.

 

Option D. Leigh syndrome: A neurodegenerative mitochondrial disorder characterized by progressive loss of mental and movement abilities. Though it can present with ataxia and cranial nerve deficits, it is not associated with phytanic acid accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical presentation of sensorineural deafness, retinitis pigmentosa, polyneuropathy, and elevated phytanic acid levels is characteristic of Refsum's disease, a rare genetic disorder resulting from a defect in the metabolism of phytanic acid.

questions.text: Which of the following H1 blocker has high anti-cholinergic activity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chlorpheniramine

 

  • Chlorpheniramine, a first-generation H1 blocker (antihistamine), has significant anticholinergic activity, which is a common characteristic of many older antihistamines.
  • This anticholinergic effect can lead to side effects such as dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation, and urinary retention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cetirizine: While cetirizine is a second-generation antihistamine with less sedative effects compared to first-generation antihistamines, it has lower anticholinergic activity than chlorpheniramine.

 

Option C. Fexofenadine: Fexofenadine is a second-generation antihistamine with minimal to no anticholinergic activity, making it less likely to cause anticholinergic side effects.

 

Option D. Astemizole: Astemizole is a second-generation antihistamine that has been withdrawn from the market in many countries due to serious cardiac side effects. It also has lower anticholinergic activity compared to first-generation antihistamines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Among the H1 blockers listed, chlorpheniramine, a first-generation antihistamine, has significant anticholinergic activity, which is responsible for many of the side effects associated with first-generation antihistamines.
  • Second-generation antihistamines, like cetirizine and fexofenadine, have been designed to reduce these side effects.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient is being treated with ciprofloxacin for acute prostatitis. 4 days later, he develops a diffuse maculopapular rash over his torso and extremities. Urinalysis reveals leukocytes and WBC casts without bacteria. What condition does this presentation suggest?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute interstitial nephritis

 

  • The development of a diffuse maculopapular rash, leukocytes, and white blood cell casts in the urine after starting ciprofloxacin suggests an allergic reaction affecting the kidneys, characteristic of acute interstitial nephritis (AIN).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IgA nephropathy typically presents with hematuria and is not commonly associated with drug reactions.

 

Option C. Obstructive uropathy would not usually cause a systemic rash or present with WBC casts without bacteria.

 

Option D. Post-infectious glomerulonephritis usually occurs after infection, not associated with a new onset rash or directly following antibiotic treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The combination of a new maculopapular rash, recent medication initiation, and renal findings such as leukocytes and WBC casts, particularly in the absence of bacteria, suggests acute interstitial nephritis, a hypersensitivity reaction within the renal interstitium, commonly caused by medications like antibiotics.

choices.text: Symptoms tend to be more pronounced in females than in males
The rectum and prostate are inherently resistant to gonococcal infection
Dysuria is the most common presenting symptom in patients
A single dose of ciprofloxacin is the treatment of choice

questions.text: A primary care physician is evaluating a patient who presents with a complaint of dysuria and a purulent urethral discharge. The patient's sexual history suggests a risk of sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Based on the history and clinical presentation, the physician suspects gonococcal urethritis. Which of the following statements about gonococcal urethritis is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dysuria is the most common presenting symptom in patients

 

  • Gonococcal urethritis, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, often presents with dysuria and purulent discharge in males.
  • Dysuria is indeed one of the most common symptoms of this condition in males, and the clinical presentation can aid in distinguishing it from non-gonococcal urethritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Symptoms tend to be more pronounced in females than in males: Incorrect, as symptoms are often more pronounced in males, and many females with gonococcal infections are asymptomatic or have mild symptoms that can be overlooked.

 

Option B. The rectum and prostate are inherently resistant to gonococcal infection: Incorrect, as the rectum can be infected through receptive anal intercourse, and the prostate can be involved in cases of disseminated gonococcal infection.

 

Option D. A single dose of ciprofloxacin is the treatment of choice: Incorrect, because Neisseria gonorrhoeae has developed resistance to fluoroquinolones like ciprofloxacin in many areas. The current CDC guidelines recommend a combination therapy with ceftriaxone and azithromycin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-gonococcal Urethritis (NGU) caused by: 

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis (D-K)
  • Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • Mycoplasma genitalium
  • Mycoplasma hominis
  • Herpes simplex virus
  • Candida albicans
  • Trichomonas vaginalis

choices.text: Nodular type is the commonest clinical presentation in this condition
PUVA therapy is a risk factor for this condition
Early diagnosis in Pre-malignant stage is crucial for the prognosis of this condition

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with a cancerous growth on his face. A diagnosis of Basal Cell Carcinoma is made based on Biopsy findings which showed characteristic peripheral palisading of tumour cells. Which of the following statements is Incorrect regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Early diagnosis in the pre-malignant stage is crucial for the prognosis of this condition

 

  • Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) does not have a pre-malignant stage, as it is a primary skin cancer that originates from the basal cells of the epidermis.
  • It typically presents as a local growth and early diagnosis is important to prevent local tissue destruction, but the term "pre-malignant" is not appropriate for BCC because it implies a transition from a pre-cancerous lesion to cancer, which is not characteristic of this condition.
  • Basal Cell Carcinoma Clinical features: Presents as Pearly translucent nodule with surface telangiectasia, undergoes central necrosis resulting in rodent ulcer with a rolled-out margin.
  • Nodular type is the commonest clinical type of basal cell carcinoma.
  • Below image depicts the Nodular Basal Cell Carcinoma

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nodular type is the commonest clinical presentation in this condition: The nodular form of BCC is the most frequently observed variant and is characterized by a pearly, often ulcerated nodule.

 

Option B. PUVA therapy is a risk factor for this condition: PUVA (psoralen plus UVA) therapy, used for various skin conditions like psoriasis, increases the risk of skin cancer, including BCC.

 

Option D. Metastasis is rare: BCC is known for local invasiveness, but it rarely metastasizes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Basal Cell Carcinoma is a skin cancer that originates from basal cells of the epidermis, typically presenting as a nodular growth, and while early diagnosis is important to prevent extensive local damage, there is no pre-malignant stage.
  • PUVA therapy is a known risk factor, and metastasis is rare in this condition.

choices.text: Endometrial aspiration biopsy
Pap smear

questions.text: A 55-year-old post-menopausal woman presents to OPD with post-menopausal bleeding. Her USG shows endometrial thickness of 7mm. Next step in management is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometrial aspiration biopsy

 

  • In post-menopausal women presenting with post-menopausal bleeding, an endometrial thickness of greater than 4mm on ultrasonography warrants further evaluation to rule out endometrial pathology, including hyperplasia and carcinoma.
  • Endometrial aspiration biopsy is a minimally invasive procedure that allows for histopathological evaluation of the endometrial tissue, which is crucial for the diagnosis and management of the underlying cause of bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CA 125: This tumor marker is often used in the evaluation of ovarian cancer and is not the first-line investigation for post-menopausal bleeding.

 

Option C. Pap smear: While important for screening for cervical cancer, a Pap smear is not the primary investigation for post-menopausal bleeding related to endometrial pathology.

 

Option D. Prepare for hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is a definitive treatment for various gynecological conditions but is not the first step in the management of post-menopausal bleeding. A biopsy and diagnosis are necessary before considering such an invasive procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the evaluation of post-menopausal bleeding, an endometrial thickness greater than 4mm on ultrasound necessitates further investigation.
  • An endometrial aspiration biopsy is the next step in management to obtain a histopathological diagnosis, which is essential for determining the appropriate treatment.

choices.text: It resolves spontaneously in postpartum period
Herpes simplex virus-1 is responsible for cross reaction with skin antigens & antibody formation
Associated with antibodies against BP180 antigen

questions.text: A primigravida in her 3rd trimester develops intensely itchy grouped vesicles in the periumbilical area. A diagnosis of Herpes gestationis is made based on these features.  Which of the following is Incorrect statement among the following options regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex virus-1 is responsible for cross reaction with skin antigens & antibody formation

 

  • Herpes gestationis or pemphigoid gestationis is a variant of Bullous pemphigoid in pregnancy (Not due to Herpes virus) and is associated with antibodies against BP-180/BPAG-2.
  • The initial site of involvement is the periumbilical region.

 

 

 

  • It presents in the 2nd or 3rd trimesters with itchy, grouped vesicles (so Herpes word used in the name of the disease) in the periumbilical area that later spread to the abdomen, trunk, thighs.
  • Prognosis: It flares in the intrapartum/Delivery period and tends to resolves spontaneously in the postpartum period.
  • Future outcome: It can recur in subsequent pregnancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It resolves spontaneously in the postpartum period: Pemphigoid gestationis often resolves after delivery, although it can recur in subsequent pregnancies or during menstrual periods.

 

Option C. Associated with antibodies against BP180 antigen: Pemphigoid gestationis is associated with the formation of autoantibodies against the BP180 antigen, a component of the hemidesmosomes in the basement membrane of the skin.

 

Option D. Variant of Bullous Pemphigoid: Pemphigoid gestationis is considered a variant of bullous pemphigoid that specifically occurs during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigoid gestationis is an autoimmune condition associated with pregnancy, characterized by the formation of autoantibodies against skin antigens, particularly the BP180 antigen.
  • It is not related to the Herpes simplex virus.
