questions.text: In a briefing about the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) for new healthcare workers, a supervisor discusses the range of conditions that the program targets for early screening in children. The workers are presented with a list of conditions and asked to identify which one is not specifically highlighted in the RBSK's outlined categories. Based on the program's focus areas, which of the following conditions is not explicitly covered?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Convulsive disorders

 

  • Convulsive disorders are not specifically listed in the RBSK program's outlined categories, making them the correct choice.
  • While the program covers a broad spectrum of health issues, convulsive disorders are not explicitly mentioned, suggesting they might be addressed within broader categories or other health initiatives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital hypothyroidism is included under 'Developmental delays including disabilities,' signifying a targeted focus within the RBSK program for early identification and intervention.

 

Option C. Neural tube defects fall under the category of 'Defects at birth'. The RBSK program emphasizes early screening for such congenital anomalies to facilitate timely management and intervention.

 

Option D. Vitamin D deficiency is categorized under 'Deficiency conditions'. The program explicitly aims to screen for nutritional deficiencies among children, recognizing the critical role of adequate nutrition in early childhood development.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following diuretics cause hypercalcemia and can be used in recurrent renal calcium stones?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chlorthiazide

 

  • Chlorthiazide is a thiazide diuretic that can cause mild hypercalcemia by increasing calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule of the nephron.
  • This property makes thiazide diuretics, like chlorthiazide, useful in the management of recurrent renal calcium stones, as they reduce the calcium excretion in urine, diminishing the risk of stone formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spironolactone: An aldosterone antagonist that primarily affects sodium and water balance and has little direct effect on calcium levels.

 

Option B. Furosemide: A loop diuretic that can actually lead to hypocalcemia by increasing calcium excretion in the urine, contrary to the effect of thiazides.

 

Option D. Mannitol: An osmotic diuretic that does not significantly affect calcium levels and is not used in the management of calcium stones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thiazide diuretics, such as chlorthiazide, can lead to mild hypercalcemia and are used in the prevention of recurrent renal calcium stones by reducing urinary calcium excretion.

questions.text: A patient undergoing neurological evaluation exhibits increased muscle tone that fluctuates irregularly, persists throughout the range of motion, and impacts both flexor and extensor muscles to the same extent. How should this presentation be best described?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paratonia

 

  • Paratonia is a form of increased muscle tone characterized by involuntary variable resistance during passive movement.
  • It is often associated with dementia and other conditions that impair cognitive function, and unlike rigidity or spasticity, the resistance is not consistent and can fluctuate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rigidity: In rigidity, muscle tone is increased uniformly and is often described as "lead-pipe" rigidity when constant throughout the range of motion or "cogwheel" rigidity if there is a ratchet-like variation in resistance due to superimposed tremor. Rigidity affects both groups of muscles equally.

 

Option C. Spasticity: This is a velocity-dependent increase in tonic stretch reflexes with exaggerated tendon jerks, resulting from hyperexcitability of the stretch reflex and is typically seen in disorders of the corticospinal tract.

 

Option D. Flaccidity: Characterized by decreased muscle tone and is often seen immediately after a spinal cord injury or stroke, before spasticity sets in.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Paratonia is distinguished by variable resistance during passive movement, often related to cognitive dysfunction.

choices.text: Between skull and dura mater

questions.text: In the investigation of a victim found in the aftermath of a building fire, a forensic expert notes a specific type of hematoma during the autopsy. This hematoma, known as a "heat hematoma," is observed in cases where the head has been exposed to intense heat, leading to charring of the skull. Understanding its typical location is crucial for the Expert to assess the extent of thermal damage and its contribution to the cause of death. Where is a heat hematoma typically located?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Between skull and dura mater

 

  • Heat haematoma occurs when the head has been exposed to intense heat, sufficient to cause charring of the skull.
  • It has the appearance of extradural haemorrhage, but is not accompanied by any signs of injury by blunt force.
  • It consists of a soft, friable clot of light chocolate colour, and may be pink, if the blood contains CO.
  • The clot has a honeycomb appearance due to bubbles of steam produced by heat.
  • The adjacent brain shows hardening and discolouration from the heat. 
  • The parietotemporal region is the most common site and sometimes frontal or occipital region.
  • It may be due to blood being boiled from the diploic layer of bone through emissary veins and venous sinus which rupture or shrinkage of meninges and brain. 
  • Heat haematoma will contain carboxyhemoglobin, but extradural haemorrhage caused by injury before the fire began, will not show carboxyhaemoglobin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inside the brain: This would be more indicative of an intracerebral hematoma, which is different from a heat (epidural) hematoma.

 

Option C. Between skull and pericranium: This space is not typically where a heat (epidural) hematoma forms. Hematomas in this location would be more superficial and not involve the meningeal arteries.

 

Option D. Between scalp and pericranium: Hematomas in this location are typically subgaleal hematomas, which are different from epidural (heat) hematomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Heat hematoma typically located between skull and dura mater.
  • EDH due to burn Vs blunt forces:

choices.text: T2: > 7 cm in maximum dimension
T3a: Tumour thrombus invading ipsilateral renal vein
T3b: Tumour thrombus extending into IVC up to diaphragm
T3c: Tumour invading ipsilateral adrenal gland

questions.text: Identify the mismatch for the T stage of renal cell carcinoma:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) T3c: Tumour invading ipsilateral adrenal gland

 

  • Tumour invading ipsilateral adrenal gland is T4.
  • TNM for RCC (AJCC, 8th Ed.):
  • T1a: Tumour size up to 4 cm
  • T1b: tumour size 4 to 7 cm
  • T2: tumour size > 7 cm
  • T3a: Extending into ipsilateral renal vein
  • T3b: Extending into infra-diaphragmatic IVC
  • T3c: Extending into supra-diaphragmatic IVC
  • T4: Breach of Gerota or invasion into Ipsilateral adrenal

 

Educational objective:

 

  • RCC invading ipsilateral adrenal gland is T4.

questions.text: A pediatrician is reviewing the case of a 6-month-old male patient who presents with recurrent infections, eczema, and bleeding diathesis. The combination of symptoms raises suspicion for a primary immunodeficiency disorder. Given the constellation of symptoms and the patient's gender, the pediatrician is considering a genetic basis for the condition. Which of the following genetic mutations is most likely in this condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) X chromosome

 

  • Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome (WAS) is most commonly associated with mutations in the WAS gene located on the X chromosome.
  • This condition is X-linked recessive, meaning it predominantly affects males.
  • The WAS gene provides instructions for making a protein that is critical for cell signalling and the actin cytoskeleton's formation in blood cells, which is essential for the immune system's function and the ability to form blood clots.
  • The mutation in the X chromosome leads to the clinical triad of eczema, thrombocytopenia (low platelet count leading to bleeding), and immunodeficiency seen in Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Y chromosome: Incorrect, as the Y chromosome does not contain the gene associated with Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome.

 

Option B. Chromosome 11p22: Incorrect, this chromosomal location is not associated with Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome.

 

Option C. Chromosome 22q11: Incorrect, deletions at chromosome 22q11 are associated with DiGeorge syndrome, not Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome (WAS) is an X-linked recessive condition caused by mutations in the WAS gene on the X chromosome.
  • This condition is characterized by a triad of symptoms: eczema, thrombocytopenia (leading to bleeding), and immunodeficiency.
  • Recognizing the genetic basis of WAS is crucial for diagnosis, management, and understanding the inheritance pattern, especially in male patients presenting with the syndrome's characteristic clinical features.

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with ABO incompatibility. The characteristic feature on peripheral smear is the presence of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Microspherocytes

 

  • In cases of ABO incompatibility, especially in the neonatal setting, one of the characteristic features observed on a peripheral blood smear is the presence of microspherocytes.
  • This condition, which often leads to hemolytic disease of the newborn, involves the partial phagocytosis and destruction of red blood cells by the immune system, resulting in smaller, spherical red blood cells known as microspherocytes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fragmented RBC: Also known as schistocytes, these are typically seen in conditions involving mechanical damage to red blood cells, such as microangiopathic hemolytic anemias, rather than ABO incompatibility.

 

Option C. Polychromasia: This indicates the presence of young red blood cells (reticulocytes) in the bloodstream, suggesting active red blood cell production. While it can be seen in hemolytic diseases, it is not as specific as microspherocytosis for ABO incompatibility.

 

Option D. Elliptocytosis: This refers to the presence of elongated, oval red blood cells and is characteristic of hereditary elliptocytosis rather than ABO incompatibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In neonatal hemolytic disease resulting from ABO incompatibility, microspherocytes are a characteristic finding on the peripheral blood smear, reflecting the immune-mediated destruction of red blood cells.

choices.text: Elevated antinuclear antibody levels
Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate

questions.text: A young male presents with spontaneous knee joint pain and swelling. He had no trauma and alongside a family history suggestive of a hereditary bleeding condition. The left knee is erythematous, swollen, and tender; range of motion is limited. An X-ray of the knee shows an effusion. The synovial fluid after arthrocentesis is bloody. Laboratory analysis is likely to reveal which abnormal coagulation test result?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prolonged partial thromboplastin time

 

  • The boy in the scenario presents with a swollen, erythematous, and tender knee joint without any history of trauma but with a family history of a bleeding disorder in a family history.
  • The presence of bloody synovial fluid upon arthrocentesis suggests a bleeding diathesis. The most likely cause, given the family history and clinical presentation, would be hemophilia, which is an X-linked recessive disorder typically affecting males and causing deficiency of clotting factors VIII (hemophilia A) or IX (hemophilia B).
  • This leads to a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), which tests the intrinsic and common coagulation pathways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elevated antinuclear antibody levels: These are associated with autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus but would not be related to joint swelling and bleeding without trauma.

 

Option B. Prolonged prothrombin time: This measures the extrinsic and common coagulation pathways, typically prolonged in conditions such as vitamin K deficiency or warfarin therapy but not commonly associated with hemophilia.

 

Option C. Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate: An elevated ESR is a non-specific marker of inflammation and could be elevated in joint diseases, infections, or inflammatory conditions but would not explain the bloody effusion in the absence of trauma or an underlying bleeding disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with joint swelling and a family history of bleeding disorders, especially when associated with bloody effusion, hemophilia is a likely diagnosis, which is characterized by a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time due to a deficiency in clotting factors VIII or IX.

choices.text: End-to-end anastomosis through a ureteric catheter
Implantation into colon

questions.text: Ureterovaginal fistula should best be treated by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ureteroneocystostomy

 

  • Ureterovaginal fistula often results from surgical injury and involves an abnormal connection between the ureter and the vagina, leading to continuous urinary leakage.
  • Ureteroneocystostomy, the surgical reimplantation of the ureter into the bladder, is considered the best treatment as it aims to restore the normal anatomy and function of the urinary system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. End-to-end anastomosis through a ureteric catheter: This might be considered for ureteral injuries but is less suitable for ureterovaginal fistulas, which often require reimplantation into the bladder due to the location and nature of the injury.

 

Option C. Implantation into colon: This is not a standard treatment for ureterovaginal fistulas and is more relevant for managing complex urinary diversions in cases like severe bladder disease or when the bladder cannot be used.

 

Option D. Ileal conduit: While this is a form of urinary diversion used in cases where the bladder is either removed or non-functional, it's not typically the first-line treatment for ureterovaginal fistulas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The management of ureterovaginal fistulas typically involves surgical repair aimed at restoring the normal anatomy.
  • Ureteroneocystostomy is considered the best treatment for these fistulas, as it reimplants the ureter into the bladder, thereby correcting the abnormal connection to the vagina.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy has a history of recurrent dislocation of the right shoulder. On examination, the orthopedician puts the patient in the supine position and abducts his arm to 90° with the bed as the fulcrum and then externally rotates it but the boy does not allow the test to be performed. The test done by the orthopedician is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Apprehension test

 

  • The apprehension test is performed to assess for anterior shoulder instability, commonly due to recurrent dislocation or subluxation of the shoulder joint.
  • The test is done by abducting and externally rotating the patient's arm, which mimics the motion that typically leads to a dislocation.
  • A positive test is indicated by the patient's expression of apprehension or discomfort, suggesting the fear of dislocation, as seen in this scenario where the boy does not allow the test to be fully performed due to discomfort or fear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sulcus test: This test evaluates inferior instability of the shoulder by pulling the arm downward and observing for a depression or 'sulcus' below the acromion.

 

Option C. Dugas test: Used to diagnose dislocation of the shoulder joint by having the patient touch the opposite shoulder with the hand of the affected arm, which would be difficult or impossible in the case of a dislocation.

 

Option D. McMurray's test: This is a test used in the examination of the knee to detect tears of the menisci.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The apprehension test is a diagnostic tool for assessing anterior shoulder instability.
  • A positive test, indicated by the patient's expression of apprehension or discomfort during the manoeuvre, suggests a high likelihood of recurrent shoulder dislocation or subluxation. Top of Form

choices.text: Severe allergic reaction – recommend immediate administration of epinephrine
Febrile seizure – recommend antipyretic therapy and observation
Localized pain and swelling at the injection site – recommend cold compresses and pain relief medication
Anaphylaxis – recommend referral to the emergency department for further management

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant, Krish, is presented to the pediatric clinic with symptoms of a high-pitched cough, runny nose, and a mild fever. Upon inquiry, the mother reveals that Krish received his pertussis vaccine two days ago. The physician considers the possibility of a vaccine-related adverse event. Which of the following is the most common side effect of the pertussis vaccine, and how should it be managed in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Localized pain and swelling at the injection site – recommend cold compresses and pain relief medication

 

  • The most common side effects of the pertussis vaccine are minor and include localized pain, redness, and swelling at the injection site, as well as mild fever.
  • These symptoms are typically self-limiting and can be managed with simple measures such as cold compresses to reduce swelling and over-the-counter pain relief medication to manage discomfort.
  • The symptoms described by Krish's mother do not indicate a severe allergic reaction or anaphylaxis, which are much less common and would present with more severe systemic symptoms.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Severe allergic reaction – recommend immediate administration of epinephrine: Severe allergic reaction would present immediately after vaccination and would be more acute and severe than the symptoms described.

 

Option B. Febrile seizure – recommend antipyretic therapy and observation: Febrile seizures are a rare side effect of the pertussis vaccine and are associated with high fever, which is not the case here as the fever is described as mild.

 

Option D. Anaphylaxis – recommend referral to the emergency department for further management: Anaphylaxis is a very rare but serious reaction that would typically occur within minutes to hours after vaccination, presenting with signs such as difficulty breathing, hives, swelling of the face and throat, a rapid heartbeat, and severe weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Localized pain and swelling are the most common side effects of the pertussis vaccine, typically resolving within a few days.
  • Management includes cold compresses and pain relief medication, with parental monitoring for any signs of infection at the injection site.

choices.text: Alpha Feto Protein
Beta hCG
Inhibin A

questions.text: All are serum analytes used in prenatal screening for Down Syndrome in the 2nd trimester except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) PAPP-A

 

  • PAPP-A (Pregnancy-Associated Plasma Protein A) is a serum analyte used in the first-trimester prenatal screening for Down Syndrome, not in the second trimester.
  • It is typically measured alongside free beta-hCG as part of the combined first-trimester screening test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha Feto Protein (AFP): AFP is a serum analyte measured in the second trimester as part of the quad screen for prenatal screening, which can help in assessing the risk of Down Syndrome and other conditions.

 

Option B. Beta hCG: Human chorionic gonadotropin (beta hCG) is measured in both the first and second trimesters. In the second trimester, it is part of the quad screen for assessing the risk of Down Syndrome.

 

Option C. Inhibin A: Inhibin A is another component of the quad screen used in the second trimester for prenatal screening of Down Syndrome.

Educational Objective:

 

  • PAPP-A is used in the first-trimester prenatal screening for Down Syndrome, whereas AFP, beta hCG, and Inhibin A are part of the second-trimester quad screen for assessing the risk of Down Syndrome.

questions.text: In a primary care clinic, a 45-year-old male patient with a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases is undergoing a routine health evaluation. The physician is concerned about the patient's risk factors for obesity-related complications, given his visibly disproportionate body fat distribution. To guide further management, the physician considers various indices to assess the patient's obesity level accurately. Recognizing the need to select an index that doesn't rely solely on height and weight due to the patient's unique body composition, which of the following indices should the physician consider that does not incorporate the patient's height in its calculation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Corpulence Index

 

  • Corpulence Index is an indicator of Obesity; calculated as -

 

CI = Actual weight/Desirable weight

 

  • Normal CI is up to 1.2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Body mass index (BMI): BMI calculates obesity by dividing weight by the square of height, thus directly involving height.

 

Option B. Ponderal index: The Ponderal Index, similar to BMI, calculated by height divided by the cube root of body weight.

 

Option C. Broca’s index: Broca’s Index uses height to estimate ideal body weight.

 

Ideal weight = Height (cms)–100

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Corpulence Index, unlike traditional measures such as BMI, Ponderal Index, and Broca's Index, does not directly use the patient's height in its calculation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with a history of severe contamination fears that interfere with her daily functioning is undergoing cognitive-behavioural therapy. Her therapist decides to use a technique where the therapist actively demonstrates healthy behaviours in hope that the patient will learn through observation. During the session, the therapist touches various objects in the room and encourages the patient to do the same, while maintaining a reassuring dialogue. The patient is instructed to practice this behaviour at home. This type of therapy is best described as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Modelling

 

  • Modelling is a therapeutic technique where the patient is encouraged to observe and imitate a behaviour demonstrated by the therapist.
  • In the case described, the patient with contamination phobia is asked to follow the therapist and touch everything he touches, with the therapist providing a calm and reassuring presence, which serves as a model for the patient to emulate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flooding involves exposing the patient to a large amount of an undesirable stimulus in order to extinguish the anxiety response, which is not what's described here.

 

Option C. Positive reinforcement would involve providing a reward after a desired behaviour is exhibited, which isn't mentioned in the scenario.

 

Option D. Aversion therapy involves pairing an unwanted behaviour with an unpleasant stimulus to reduce the occurrence of the behaviour, which isn't the case in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Modelling is a therapeutic technique to help patients learn through observation and imitation, particularly in the treatment of phobias and anxiety disorders.

questions.text: A patient with a history of muscle weakness is undergoing electrophysiological testing to assess their nerve conduction system. During the testing, the healthcare team observes that no stimulus, regardless of strength, is able to excite the nerve tissue for a specific duration. Which refractory period is most likely responsible for this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Absolute refractory period

 

  • During the absolute refractory period, the nerve is completely unresponsive to further stimulation because the sodium channels are inactivated, and no action potential can be initiated.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Relative refractory period: Incorrect. In the relative refractory period, a stronger-than normal stimulus can initiate another action potential, albeit with more difficulty.

 

Option C. Suprathreshold refractory period: Incorrect. This is not a standard term used in the context of refractory periods.

 

Option D. Repolarization refractory period: Incorrect. Repolarization is a phase within the action potential, and while it overlaps with the refractory period concept, it is not a term used to describe a refractory period per se.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The objective is to recognize the characteristics of the absolute refractory period and its role in the temporal regulation of action potential initiation in nerve conduction studies.

choices.text: The shaft is triangular in the upper half & cylindrical in lower part in cross-section
The shaft has 2 borders and 3 surfaces
The shaft has 3 borders & 3 surfaces
Upper third of the lateral border forms the lateral lip of intertubercular sulcus

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with severe pain in his left arm. The patient reports falling off a ladder approximately two hours prior to presentation. On radiological examination, everything was seen normal as shown in image. Which of the following statements is true about the shaft of the pointed structure A in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The shaft has 3 borders & 3 surfaces

 

  • The indicated radiological image is showing transverse view of arm & indicated bone A is showing the shaft of humerus.
  • The shaft of humerus presents 3 surfaces: Anteromedial, anterolateral & posterior surfaces.

 

 

  • Bony landmarks & attachment of humerus shown in image:

 

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. The shaft is triangular in the upper half & cylindrical in lower part in cross-section:  The proximal or upper half of the humerus shaft does tend to have a more cylindrical cross-section whereas in the lower half, the humerus becomes more cylindrical. This triangular shape is better suited for the hinge-type joint at the elbow and provides a more uniform surface for muscle attachments and the interlocking of bones at the elbow joint.

 

Option B. The shaft has 2 borders and 3 surfaces: This statement is not accurate. The shaft of the humerus typically has three borders (anterior, medial, and lateral) and three surfaces (anterolateral, anteromedial, and posterior). These borders and surfaces serve as attachment sites for muscles and provide structural integrity.

 

Option D. Upper third of the lateral border forms the lateral lip of intertubercular sulcus: The bicipital groove runs along the proximal end of the humerus and gives attachment to the tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii muscle. The lateral border runs from the back part of the greater tubercle to the lateral epicondyle, and separates the anterolateral surface from posterior surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The shaft has 3 borders and 3 surfaces.
  • 3 Borders: Anterior, Medial, and Lateral.
  • 3 Surfaces: Antero-lateral, Antero-medial, and Posterior.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy upper limb and thorax, Vishram Singh, 3rd edition, page no. 9

choices.text: Maple Syrup Urine Disease

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with complaints of eye pain. On examination, multiple corneal erosions are noted, along with hyperkeratotic lesions on the palms and soles. Laboratory investigations reveal a deficiency of and enzyme. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Richner-Hanhart syndrome

 

  • Tyrosinemia Type II or Richner-Hanhart syndrome is a disorder marked by ocular findings, such as corneal erosions, and skin changes like palmar and plantar hyperkeratosis, related to tyrosine transaminase deficiency.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hartnup Disease: A metabolic disorder characterized by pellagra-like skin lesions and neurological symptoms due to the body's inability to absorb certain amino acids, including tryptophan.

 

Option C. Maple Syrup Urine Disease: A metabolic disorder characterized by a distinctive sweet odour of urine and progressive neurological deterioration, caused by a deficiency in the branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase complex.

 

Option D. Fabry Disease: A lysosomal storage disorder resulting in the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide, leading to pain in the extremities, angiokeratomas, and renal dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tyrosinemia Type II, also known as Richner-Hanhart syndrome, should be suspected in a child with corneal erosions, hyperkeratotic lesions on the palms and soles, and a confirmed deficiency of tyrosine transaminase.

questions.text: Which cellular organelle is significantly abundant in oncocytes, giving them a distinct histological appearance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mitochondria

 

  • Oncocytes are cells characterized by an abundant, granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm that is due to a large number of mitochondria.
  • These cells can be found in various organs and are often associated with certain benign and malignant tumors, such as oncocytomas.
  •  The abundance of mitochondria gives these cells their distinctive appearance under microscopic examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysosomes: These are organelles involved in degradation and recycling of cellular waste, not related to the characteristic features of oncocytes.

 

Option B. Endoplasmic reticulum: While important for protein and lipid synthesis, modifications of the endoplasmic reticulum do not lead to the formation of oncocytes.

 

Option D. Nucleus: This option is incorrect as mitochondria are indeed the organelles associated with the formation of oncocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oncocytes are cells characterized by a high content of mitochondria, giving them a granular, eosinophilic appearance in the cytoplasm.
  • They can be seen in certain tumors and are indicative of mitochondrial alterations within the cell.

choices.text: Zona penetration assay
DNA fragmentation index
Hypoosmotic swelling test
Mannose fluorescence assay

questions.text: Which of the following tests can differentiate between dead and non-motile sperm?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypoosmotic swelling test

 

  • The hypoosmotic swelling test (HOS test) is used to differentiate between dead and non-motile sperm.
  • It assesses the functional integrity of the sperm cell membrane by observing the ability of the sperm cell to swell under hypoosmotic conditions.
  • Live, non-motile sperm will swell due to intact cell membranes, while dead sperm cells will not respond to the hypoosmotic environment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zona penetration assay: This test assesses the ability of sperm to penetrate the zona pellucida of an egg, which is an indicator of fertilizing capability, not a differentiation between dead and non-motile sperm.

 

Option B. DNA fragmentation index: This test evaluates the integrity of sperm DNA. Higher levels of fragmentation can indicate compromised fertility potential but do not distinguish between dead and non-motile sperm.

 

Option D. Mannose fluorescence assay: This is not a commonly used test in the evaluation of sperm viability or motility. Mannose-binding lectins can be used in certain assays for other purposes, but this does not apply to differentiating dead from non-motile sperm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The hypoosmotic swelling test (HOS test) is a useful assay in andrology to distinguish live, non-motile sperm from dead sperm by evaluating the functional integrity of the sperm cell membrane through their response to hypoosmotic conditions.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man was admitted to the ICU for chronic renal failure. Due to long term hospitalization, the patient was a bit malnourished and Vitamin deficiencies started to manifest. Which of the following is used for functional assessment of Vitamin B1 deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) RBC transketolase

 

  • RBC transketolase activity is used for the functional assessment of Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency.
  • Thiamine is a cofactor for the transketolase enzyme involved in the pentose phosphate pathway.
  • In cases of thiamine deficiency, the activity of transketolase in red blood cells (RBCs) is reduced.
  • Measurement of RBC transketolase activity, particularly the increase in its activity after the addition of thiamine pyrophosphate (the active form of thiamine) in vitro, can indicate a deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum thiamine levels: While this measures the direct level of thiamine, it is less commonly used for assessing functional thiamine deficiency.

 

 

Option B. RBC glutathione peroxidase: This enzyme is associated with selenium status, not thiamine.

 

Option D. RBC glutathione reductase: This enzyme is involved in the antioxidant defense and is used to assess riboflavin (Vitamin B2) status, not thiamine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The assessment of Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency is functionally determined by measuring the activity of RBC transketolase, which requires thiamine as a cofactor.
  • This test reflects the biochemical functionality of thiamine in the body rather than just its concentration.

questions.text: A 28-year-old sexually active female presents to the emergency department with redness, purulent discharge, and marked eyelid swelling in the left eye. On further evaluation, the diagnosis of gonococcal conjunctivitis is confirmed. Which of the following complications is the patient at the highest risk for if left untreated?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Corneal Ulceration

 

  • Untreated gonococcal conjunctivitis can lead to severe corneal involvement, including corneal ulceration.
  • This complication results from the direct invasion of Neisseria gonorrhoeae into the cornea and can cause significant vision impairment.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Cataract Formation: While cataract formation is a potential complication of ocular infections, it is not the primary concern in gonococcal conjunctivitis. Corneal involvement and subsequent complications are more common in this condition.

 

Option C. Retinal Detachment: Retinal detachment is not typically associated with gonococcal conjunctivitis. It occurs due to the separation of the retina from the underlying tissue and is not a common sequela of this type of conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Optic Neuritis: Optic neuritis refers to inflammation of the optic nerve and can lead to vision impairment. It is not a direct complication of gonococcal conjunctivitis. Complications in gonococcal conjunctivitis usually involve the anterior segment of the eye, such as the cornea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The patient with gonococcal conjunctivitis is at the highest risk for the complication of Corneal ulceration.
  • This complication can result in significant vision loss and highlights the importance of early diagnosis and treatment of gonococcal conjunctivitis to prevent severe ocular damage.

questions.text: Mrs. Johnson, a 60-year-old woman, has been experiencing fatigue and generalized swelling for several weeks. Concerned about her symptoms, she decides to consult her primary care physician. During the examination, her physician measures of renal clearance rates for specific substances. Which of the following substances has the lowest renal clearance rate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urea

 

  • Urea is a waste product that is produced in the liver as a result of protein metabolism and is excreted by the kidneys.
  • Urea is partially reabsorbed in the renal tubules, which means that not all of it is filtered and excreted in the urine.
  • As a result, urea has a lower renal clearance rate compared to substances that are not significantly reabsorbed, such as creatinine and inulin.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Creatinine is a waste product that is produced from the breakdown of creatine in muscles. It is freely filtered at the glomerulus and is not reabsorbed in the renal tubules. This property makes creatinine a commonly used marker for estimating the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) since its clearance rate reflects the GFR. It has a relatively high renal clearance rate.

 

Option C. Inulin: A natural polysaccharide that is not produced in the body and is not metabolized. It is completely filtered at the glomerulus, and unlike urea, it is not reabsorbed in the renal tubules. This makes inulin an ideal substance for measuring GFR as its clearance rate provides an accurate reflection of the GFR.

 

Option D. All have equal clearance: is statement is not accurate. The clearance rates of these substances are not equal. Urea has a lower clearance rate due to partial reabsorption, while creatinine and inulin have higher clearance rates because they are not significantly reabsorbed.

 

  • So, the correct answer is option A. Urea, as it has the lowest renal clearance rate among the provided options.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Assess the understanding of renal clearance rates for specific substances used in evaluating kidney function and the ability to identify the substance with the lowest clearance rate in a clinical context.

questions.text: A patient receives a toxic dose of IV lignocaine. The patient is likely to exhibit:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Seizures and coma

 

  • A toxic dose of lignocaine (lidocaine), a local anesthetic, can affect the central nervous system and lead to neurological symptoms such as seizures due to its CNS stimulatory effects at toxic levels.
  • In severe cases, this can progress to coma.
  • Initially, CNS excitation may occur, followed by CNS depression leading to respiratory failure if not promptly managed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive salivation: This is not typically associated with lignocaine toxicity.

 

Option B. Mydriasis and diarrhea: These are not common manifestations of lignocaine toxicity.

 

Option C. Respiratory paralysis: While severe lignocaine toxicity can lead to CNS depression and potentially respiratory failure, the direct presentation is more commonly seizures and potential progression to coma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary manifestations of lignocaine toxicity include CNS effects such as seizures and potentially coma due to its CNS stimulatory effects at toxic levels.
  • Early recognition and management are crucial to prevent severe complications such as respiratory failure.

choices.text: Centrally acting reversible anticholinesterase
Centrally acting irreversible anticholinesterase

questions.text: Mechanism of action of donepezil is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Centrally acting reversible anticholinesterase

 

  • Donepezil is a centrally acting reversible inhibitor of the enzyme acetylcholinesterase.
  • It is used in the management of Alzheimer's disease to increase the concentration of acetylcholine in the brain by preventing its breakdown, thereby enhancing cholinergic transmission.
  • This can lead to a modest improvement in cognitive function and symptoms in patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Centrally acting irreversible anticholinesterase: Donepezil is not an irreversible inhibitor; its action on acetylcholinesterase is reversible.

 

Option C. Irreversible cholinergic action: This option is incorrect as donepezil does not have an irreversible cholinergic action; it reversibly inhibits acetylcholinesterase.

 

Option D. Reversible anticholinesterase: While this is partially correct in describing donepezil’s mechanism, it lacks the specification that donepezil's action is predominantly central (in the brain), which is crucial for its therapeutic use in Alzheimer's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Donepezil is a centrally acting reversible anticholinesterase used in the management of Alzheimer's disease.
  • It works by increasing the concentration of acetylcholine in the brain, improving cholinergic function and cognitive symptoms in affected patients.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent episodes of muscle rigidity and dark urine, when exposed to general anesthesia. His serum creatine kinase levels are significantly elevated during these episodes. Genetic testing is most likely to reveal a mutation in gene, which is located on which chromosome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chromosome 19

 

  • The ryanodine receptor gene (RYR1), which plays a crucial role in calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscle cells, is located on chromosome 19.
  • Mutations in this gene can lead to conditions such as malignant hyperthermia and central core disease.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Chromosome 1: The gene for cystic fibrosis (CFTR) is located on chromosome 1. Mutations in this gene lead to cystic fibrosis, a condition characterized by the production of abnormally thick mucus leading to severe respiratory and digestive problems.

 

Option B. Chromosome 4: The gene responsible for Huntington's disease, HTT, is found on chromosome 4. Huntington's disease is an inherited neurodegenerative disorder that leads to motor dysfunction, cognitive decline, and psychiatric issues.

 

Option C. Chromosome 11: The beta-globin gene cluster, which includes the sickle cell gene, is on chromosome 11. Mutations in these genes can cause sickle cell anemia or other hemoglobinopathies, diseases affecting the structure or production of hemoglobin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ryanodine receptor gene (RYR1) is located on chromosome 19.
  • Mutations in RYR1 can cause susceptibility to malignant hyperthermia, an autosomal dominant pharmacogenetic disorder of skeletal muscle that can be triggered by certain anesthetics and leads to a hypermetabolic state.

choices.text: Active and infectious Hepatitis B disease

questions.text: A nurse working in a hospital's infectious disease unit has recently been feeling fatigued and experiencing mild abdominal discomfort. During a routine screening, her blood tests reveal the presence of both HBeAg and HBsAg. Given these findings, the infectious disease specialist is trying to ascertain the stage and nature of her hepatitis B infection to guide further management and precautions. Which of the following is most likely indicated by the presence of HBeAg and HBsAg in her serum?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Active and infectious Hepatitis B disease

 

  • The presence of HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) indicates an ongoing Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection.
  • The additional presence of HBeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen) is a marker of viral replication, suggesting that the virus is actively replicating in the liver.
  • This combination indicates a high level of infectivity and an active phase of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic hepatitis B is defined by the persistence of HBsAg for more than 6 months. Without information on the duration HBsAg has been present, a diagnosis of chronic hepatitis B cannot be definitively made.

 

Option B. HBV + HBe coinfection: The term "HBV + HBe coinfection" is not accurate. HBeAg is a viral protein of HBV, not a separate infectious agent. The presence of HBeAg indicates active replication of HBV.

 

Option D. Recovery from Hepatitis B is typically indicated by the loss of HBsAg and the presence of antibodies against HBsAg (anti-HBs) and possibly antibodies against HBeAg (anti-HBe).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serologic Patterns in Hepatitis B:

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with a history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus presents with decreased vision and eye pain. Ophthalmologic examination reveals inflammation in the vitreous humor, and a vitreous aspirate is obtained, the result of gram staining is shown in the below image. Based on the findings, which of the following is the most likely etiological agent responsible for the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Candida

 

  • The presence of Gram-positive round to oval cells along with pseudohyphae in the vitreous aspirate is characteristic of Candida species.
  • Candida can cause endophthalmitis, particularly in immunocompromised patients or those with uncontrolled diabetes, and it is known to produce pseudohyphae as well as yeast cells which are usually around 12-14 µm in size.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus: Incorrect, as Aspergillus species are typically filamentous fungi that form septate hyphae. They can cause eye infections but do not typically form the round to oval yeast cells seen with Candida.

 

Option B. Rhizopus: Incorrect, as Rhizopus species, part of the Mucorales order, are also filamentous fungi that do not form pseudohyphae or yeast forms. Rhizopus is associated with mucormycosis, which has a different clinical presentation.

 

Option D. Fusarium: Incorrect, as Fusarium species are filamentous fungi that produce macroconidia that can be confused with yeast cells on low-resolution examination, but they do not form pseudohyphae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of Gram-positive yeast cells and pseudohyphae in a vitreous aspirate suggests a fungal infection by Candida species, which is known to cause opportunistic infections such as endophthalmitis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals and those with uncontrolled diabetes.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases results from deficient production of free radicals?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic granulomatous disease

 

  • Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder that results from the deficient production of free radicals, specifically reactive oxygen species (ROS), by phagocytes (neutrophils and macrophages).
  • These ROS are crucial for killing certain bacteria and fungi; thus, individuals with CGD have recurrent infections due to the inability of their immune cells to effectively kill these pathogens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alzheimer’s disease: This neurodegenerative disease is associated with the accumulation of beta-amyloid plaques and tau tangles in the brain, not with a deficiency in free radical production.

 

Option B. Cancer: While oxidative stress and free radicals can contribute to DNA damage and cancer development, cancer is not caused by a deficiency in free radical production.

 

Option D. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS): This is a neurodegenerative disorder affecting motor neurons, leading to muscle weakness and atrophy. Its pathogenesis is not primarily related to deficient production of free radicals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic granulomatous disease is characterized by a defect in the immune system's ability to produce reactive oxygen species, leading to an increased susceptibility to infections.
  • It is the condition among the listed options that results directly from deficient free radical production.

choices.text: Rose position: Head and neck surgery
Lloyd Davies position: Perineal surgery
Trendelenburg position: Pelvic surgery
Reverse Trendelenburg position: Steep head low position

questions.text: Identify the mismatched patient positions for surgery from below:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reverse Trendelenburg position: Steep head low position

 

  • Reverse Trendelenburg is steep head-high position.
  • The head end of the table is tilted up, thereby placing the head higher than the feet.
  • This is useful for gastro-esophageal procedures.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rose position: slight neck extension for head and neck surgery.

 

Option B. Lloyd Davies position: Lloyd-Davies position is a modification of the lithotomy position with hips minimally flexed to around 15° with a 30° head-down tilt for gynacologic, perineal and urologic procedures.

 

Option C. Trendelenburg position: the head end of the table is tilted down on an incline with the patient’s knees slightly flexed. This is often used in pelvic procedures and when resuscitating a patient in shock

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Objectives of correct surgical positioning.
  • Facilitate safe anesthesia and surgery.
  • Reduce adverse physiological insults.
  • Optimise surgical exposure and ergonomics.

choices.text: Delusion of grandiosity and persecution
Delusion of grandiosity, persecution and reference

questions.text: A school teacher believes he is the most important person in the world and so his neighbours and family members are trying to harm him as they are jealous of him. His wife says otherwise and says he behaves like this only recently and before that he was working peacefully as a school teacher. He is most likely suffering from:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Delusion of grandiosity and persecution

 

  • The patient's belief that he is the most important person in the world is indicative of a delusion of grandiosity, which involves an exaggerated sense of one's own importance, power, or knowledge.
  • Additionally, his belief that his neighbours and family members are trying to harm him due to jealousy suggests a delusion of persecution, where an individual believes they are being conspired against, cheated, spied on, followed, poisoned or harassed, and that others are out to cause them harm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delusion of grandiosity: This alone does not encompass the patient's belief that others are trying to harm him.

 

Option B. Delusion of persecution: While this aligns with part of the patient's belief system, it does not address his exaggerated sense of self-importance.

 

Option D. Delusion of grandiosity, persecution, and reference: This option is not supported by the information provided, as there is no mention of the patient believing events or actions of others are referring specifically to him, which would indicate a delusion of reference.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Delusions of both grandiosity and persecution is based on their belief in their inflated self-importance and that others are trying to harm them due to jealousy.

questions.text: A public health officer is working in a tropical region and encounters several cases of lymphatic filariasis with varying clinical manifestations. To enhance the control measures and treatment strategies, it is crucial to identify the causative agents of the disease present in this region. Which of the following parasites is NOT responsible for causing lymphatic filariasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loa loa

 

  • Loa loa, the African eye worm, is a filarial nematode that causes loiasis, not lymphatic filariasis.
  • It is transmitted by the bite of deer flies (genus Chrysops) and is characterized by Calabar swellings and migration of the adult worm through the subconjunctival tissue of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wuchereria bancrofti: Incorrect, this is one of the primary causative agents of lymphatic filariasis and is responsible for the majority of cases worldwide.

 

Option C. Brugia malayi: Incorrect, this is also a causative agent of lymphatic filariasis, predominantly found in Asia.

 

Option D. Brugia timori: Incorrect, this is another causative agent of lymphatic filariasis, though it is less common and found in certain regions of Indonesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Wuchereria bancrofti (MC), Brugia malayi, and Brugia timori are all known to cause lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents to the clinic with a persistent cough and weight loss. A computed tomography scan of his chest shows several nodular lesions in the lungs. A biopsy of one of the lesions is performed, and histopathological examination is planned to determine the cause. The pathology team intends to use a stain that would be most effective in visualizing fungal cell walls, which could be responsible for the nodular lesions. Which stain should they use to best demonstrate the fungal cell walls and aid in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Silver methenamine stain

 

  • Silver methenamine stain, also known as Grocott's methenamine silver stain, is a staining technique commonly used to detect fungi in tissue sections.
  • It stains the fungal cell walls black, which contrasts with the surrounding tissue, making it a valuable tool for the diagnosis of fungal infections, particularly in patients with immunocompromised conditions or lung diseases.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Masson trichrome: Incorrect, this stain is used primarily to distinguish between muscle, collagen, and cytoplasm, and is not specific for fungal cell walls.

 

Option C. Alizarin red: Incorrect, Alizarin red is used for staining calcium deposits in tissues and is not specific for fungi.

 

Option D. Congo red: Incorrect, Congo red is typically used to stain amyloid deposits in tissues, not fungal organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Silver methenamine stain is preferred for fungal visualization due to its ability to bind to components of the fungal cell wall.
  • It is the first choice for broad fungal visualization.

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of anaemia/thrombocytopenia and bone pain. On Examination, hepatosplenomegaly was observed, and light microscopy reveals crumpled tissue paper appearance. The enzyme defect is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucocerebrosidase

 

  • The presentation described, including anemia, thrombocytopenia, bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and the characteristic "crumpled tissue paper" appearance of cells on light microscopy, is indicative of Gaucher's disease.
  • Gaucher's disease results from a deficiency in the enzyme glucocerebrosidase, leading to the accumulation of glucocerebroside within cells, particularly within macrophages in the liver, spleen, and bone marrow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphingomyelinase: Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Niemann-Pick disease, characterized by sphingomyelin accumulation, which can also present with hepatosplenomegaly but has a different cellular pathology.

 

Option C. Hexosaminidase A: Deficiency of this enzyme causes Tay-Sachs disease, which primarily affects the central nervous system and does not typically present with the features described.

 

Option D. Beta-galactosidase: Deficiency in this enzyme leads to GM1 gangliosidosis, which involves a different set of clinical and pathological features compared to those described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "crumpled tissue paper" appearance of cells in light microscopy, along with symptoms like anemia, thrombocytopenia, bone pain, and hepatosplenomegaly, strongly suggests Gaucher's disease, which is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

choices.text: The optic nerves are surrounded by sheaths derived from the pia mater, arachnoid mater, and dura mater.
The intracranial subarachnoid space extends forward around the optic nerve as far as the back of the eyeball.
The ciliary ganglion is situated between the proximal part of medial rectus and optic nerve.
The nerve to medial rectus is seen inferior to the optic nerve.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man was found on ophthalmoscopic examination to have bilateral papilledema and congestion of both retinal veins. The cause of the condition was found to be a rapidly expanding intracranial tumor. Which of the following statements is not correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The ciliary ganglion is situated between the proximal part of medial rectus and optic nerve.

 

  • The ciliary ganglion is actually situated in the posterior orbit but not between the optic nerve and the medial rectus.
  • It is typically located laterally to the optic nerve, near the apex of the orbit.
  • This ganglion is part of the parasympathetic pathway that controls the pupil's constriction and accommodation of the lens.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The optic nerves are surrounded by sheaths derived from the pia mater, arachnoid mater, and dura mater: True, the optic nerve is surrounded by extensions of all three meningeal layers.

 

Option B. The intracranial subarachnoid space extends forward around the optic nerve as far as the back of the eyeball: True, the subarachnoid space extends around the optic nerve, which is why increased intracranial pressure can lead to papilledema.

 

Option D. The nerve to medial rectus is seen inferior to the optic nerve: True, the branch of the oculomotor nerve that innervates the medial rectus muscle runs inferior to the optic nerve within the orbit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ciliary ganglion is located laterally to the optic nerve in the orbit, not between the optic nerve and the medial rectus.
  • It is associated with the control of pupil constriction and lens accommodation, not the visual pathway directly affected by papilledema in the presence of an intracranial tumor.

questions.text:
A pediatrician is evaluating a 3-year-old girl with a confirmed diagnosis of Rett syndrome. Which clinical characteristics are most consistent with this diagnosis?

 

 

  1. Intense eye contact

  2. Loss of purposeful hand use and repetitive hand movements

  3. Accelerated head growth

  4. GI disturbances

  5. Normal progression of language skills
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

  1. Intense eye contact: Rett syndrome typically involves a period of withdrawal and poor eye contact after initial normal development.

  2. Loss of purposeful hand use replaced by repetitive hand movements: A hallmark of Rett syndrome is the loss of purposeful hand use and development of repetitive, stereotypic hand movements such as wringing.

  3. Accelerated head growth: Head growth deceleration, not acceleration, is a characteristic feature of Rett syndrome.

  4. Gastrointestinal disturbances: Children with Rett syndrome may experience a variety of gastrointestinal issues, including constipation and gastroesophageal reflux.

  5. Normal progression of language skills: There is usually a regression of language and communication skills in children with Rett syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mnemonic to remember Rett syndrome features:
R-E-T-T = Regression, Eye-tracking preserved, Tics (hand-wringing), Tiny head

choices.text: Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML)

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with a headache and altered sensorium. MRI was performed which revealed multiple rings enhancing lesions. MR spectroscopy showed a prominent lipid-lactate peak. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculoma

 

  • The MRI findings of multiple ring-enhancing lesions in a patient with neurological symptoms such as headache and altered sensorium, along with a prominent lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy, are highly suggestive of central nervous system tuberculosis, or tuberculomas.
  • Foci of infection shows conglomerating ring enhancing lesions, common around brainstem.
  • Tuberculomas are granulomatous lesions that occur in the brain as a result of hematogenous spread from primary tuberculosis infection elsewhere in the body.
  • The lipid-lactate peak on spectroscopy is indicative of the high lipid content within these lesions and the anaerobic glycolysis taking place within the inflammatory cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurocysticercosis: Typically presents with cystic lesions showing scolex on imaging, not typically associated with a prominent lipid-lactate peak.

 

Option C. Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML): Caused by the JC virus in immunocompromised patients, PML lesions are usually non-enhancing and affect white matter without mass effect.

 

Option D. Cryptococcomas: Caused by Cryptococcus infection, these can have ring-enhancing features but are more commonly associated with immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV/AIDS, and would usually also present with "soap bubble" lesions in the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient presenting with multiple ring-enhancing lesions and a prominent lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy, tuberculoma is a likely diagnosis, especially in areas where tuberculosis is prevalent.
  • MRI and MR spectroscopy findings can aid in distinguishing between various infectious etiologies of brain lesions.

questions.text: A child did not pass meconium for 48 hours after birth. Imaging performed revealed dilated small bowel loops with atretic micro-colon. The child was stabilized and taken up for surgery. Which of these conditions is linked to the given condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystic fibrosis

 

  • Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder that affects multiple organs, including the respiratory and gastrointestinal systems.
  • It can lead to meconium ileus, a condition characterized by the obstruction of the small bowel with thick meconium, resulting in symptoms similar to those described in the scenario.
  • Therefore, cystic fibrosis is linked to the given condition.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. VACTERL: VACTERL association is a collection of congenital anomalies that often occur together. While it can involve gastrointestinal anomalies, the absence of passing meconium for 48 hours after birth with dilated small bowel loops and atretic micro-colon is not typically a feature of VACTERL association.

 

Option C. MEN 2B syndrome: Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 2B syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the development of tumors in various endocrine glands. While it can involve gastrointestinal manifestations, it is not typically associated with the presentation described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Pulmonary hypoplasia: Pulmonary hypoplasia is a condition characterized by underdevelopment of the lungs. While it can occur in conjunction with other congenital anomalies, it is not directly linked to the presentation described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cystic fibrosis is almost always the underlying cause of this condition.
  • Meconium is normally kept fluid by the action of pancreatic enzymes.
  • In meconium ileus, the terminal ileum becomes filled with thick viscid meconium, resulting in progressive intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following drug decreases plasma renin activity?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clonidine

 

  • Clonidine is a centrally acting alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that decreases sympathetic outflow from the central nervous system, which in turn reduces plasma renin activity.
  • By diminishing the sympathetic stimulation to the kidneys, clonidine indirectly leads to a decrease in renin secretion, a hormone responsible for regulating blood pressure and fluid balance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enalapril: An ACE inhibitor that can actually lead to an increase in plasma renin activity due to the inhibition of angiotensin II production, which removes the negative feedback on renin secretion.

 

Option B. Nifedipine: A calcium channel blocker used for hypertension and angina, which may lead to a reflex increase in sympathetic activity and potentially increase renin levels due to vasodilation and a drop in blood pressure.

 

Option C. Hydralazine: A direct vasodilator that can cause reflex sympathetic activation, leading to increased renin secretion as a compensatory mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clonidine decreases plasma renin activity through its central action as an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, reducing sympathetic nervous system outflow and thereby diminishing renin secretion from the kidneys.

questions.text: In complete duplication of ureters, how does the proximal ureteric segment insert inside the urinary bladder?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Caudal and medial

 

  • Ectopic ureters are usually associated with duplicate ureters (in 80% of cases).
  • Weigert-Meyer rule of Ectopic ureters:
  • Weigert Meyer rule states that the upper pole ureter is the ectopic ureter and its orifice inserts infero-medially in the bladder in relationship to the lower pole normal ureter.
  • The ureter that drains the upper moiety is at a more inferior and medial position and is prone to obstruction and dysplasia.
  • The ureter that drains the lower moiety is at a more superior and lateral position and is prone to VUR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In complete duplication of ureters, the proximal segment inserts into the urinary bladder caudally and medially.

questions.text: A 14-month-old boy is being evaluated for recurrent, indolent skin infections and gingivitis. On taking a detailed history from the mother, she tells very valuable point that he had delayed separation of the umbilical cord which occurred around 9-10 weeks after his birth. Which of the following proteins is most likely under-expressed in this boy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Integrins

 

  • The delayed separation of the umbilical cord, along with a history of recurrent skin infections and gingivitis, suggests a diagnosis of Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency (LAD), most commonly LAD type 1.
  • This condition is characterized by a deficiency or dysfunction of integrins, specifically the beta-2 integrin subunit (CD18), which is crucial for leukocyte adhesion and migration.
  • This defect impairs the ability of leukocytes to exit the bloodstream and enter sites of infection, leading to the clinical features observed in this boy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Late complement components: Deficiencies in late complement components typically lead to increased susceptibility to Neisseria infections rather than the symptoms described.

 

Option B. Transcobalamin II: This is involved in vitamin B12 transport; a deficiency would lead to problems related to B12 deficiency, such as megaloblastic anemia, not the symptoms described.

 

Option D. α2-globulins: These are plasma proteins, and their under-expression would not typically result in the clinical picture described, which is more consistent with an adhesion defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Delayed separation of the umbilical cord, recurrent skin infections, and a deficiency in wound healing are indicative of Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency (LAD), most commonly due to a defect in integrins, specifically the beta-2 integrin subunit (CD18).
  • This condition impairs leukocyte adhesion and migration to sites of infection.

choices.text: Calcium + Vitamin D supplementation

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents for a routine checkup. She has a sedentary lifestyle and her BMI is 26. She used to smoke 1 pack/day but has recently stopped. She was advised calcium and vitamin D supplementation at her last checkup but has not been taking these. She has no significant medical history. A DEXA scan is done which shows her T score as -2.5. What is the most appropriate treatment option for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bisphosphonates

 

  • Bisphosphonates are the first-line treatment option for osteoporosis, particularly in postmenopausal women, which is suggested by the patient's age.
  • A T-score of -2.5 on a DEXA scan indicates osteoporosis, and bisphosphonates work by inhibiting bone resorption, thereby increasing bone mineral density and reducing the risk of fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium + Vitamin D supplementation: While important for bone health and usually recommended as part of the management of osteoporosis, calcium and vitamin D supplementation alone may not be sufficient for treating osteoporosis with a T-score of -2.5. They are often used in conjunction with other treatments like bisphosphonates.

 

Option C. Estrogen + Progesterone: Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) can be used for osteoporosis prevention in postmenopausal women but is generally not the first choice due to associated risks, such as an increased risk of breast cancer, stroke, and heart disease. It may be considered in certain cases where other treatments are contraindicated.

 

Option D. Teriparatide: This is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone used for the treatment of osteoporosis in individuals at high risk of fracture. However, it is typically reserved for patients with severe osteoporosis who have not responded to or cannot tolerate other treatments due to its high cost and potential side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a postmenopausal woman with a sedentary lifestyle and a DEXA scan showing a T-score of -2.5 (indicating osteoporosis), the most appropriate initial treatment option would be bisphosphonates.
  • They are effective in increasing bone mineral density and reducing fracture risk in osteoporosis.
  • Calcium and vitamin D supplementation are also important but usually serve as adjunct therapy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a painless, palpable mass in her neck. Thyroid function tests reveal normal levels of thyroid hormones. Which of the following histological type of carcinoma thyroid most commonly metastasizes to lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Papillary thyroid carcinoma

 

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common type of thyroid cancer and is known for its tendency to metastasize to regional lymph nodes.
  • Even small papillary carcinomas can present with lymph node involvement, making lymphatic spread a characteristic feature of this histological subtype.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medullary thyroid carcinoma: Medullary thyroid carcinoma, arising from the parafollicular C cells, can metastasize to lymph nodes but not as commonly as papillary carcinoma.

 

Option B. Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma: Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is a rare, aggressive form of thyroid cancer that primarily spreads locally and invasively within the neck, though it can also metastasize distantly, including to lymph nodes.

 

Option D. Follicular thyroid carcinoma: Follicular thyroid carcinoma tends to spread hematogenously to distant sites like the lungs and bones rather than through lymphatic routes to lymph nodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma is notable for its propensity to spread to regional lymph nodes, more so than other histological types of thyroid cancer.
  • This feature has implications for the surgical management of the disease, often necessitating careful evaluation and possible removal of these lymph nodes during thyroid cancer surgery.

choices.text: Vitamin D supplementation
Do MRI scan
Go for screw fixation of L1 vertebra

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady got compression fracture of L1 vertebra. There is no neurological deficit to this patient. What advise will you give for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin D supplementation

 

  • For a patient with a compression fracture of the L1 vertebra without neurological deficit, conservative management is often preferred, especially in the elderly.
  • Vitamin D supplementation, along with calcium, can help improve bone density and prevent further fractures, particularly if osteoporosis is a contributing factor to the fracture.
  • Ensuring adequate vitamin D levels is crucial for bone health and healing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Do MRI scan: While an MRI can provide detailed imaging of spinal structures, it may not be immediately necessary for a compression fracture without neurological symptoms, unless there is concern for underlying pathology or the initial diagnosis needs further confirmation.

 

Option C. Go for screw fixation of L1 vertebra: Surgical intervention like screw fixation is typically reserved for fractures that are unstable, have significant vertebral body collapse, or are associated with neurological deficits.

 

Option D. To take Dexamethasone: Corticosteroids like dexamethasone are not standard treatment for compression fractures without inflammation or spinal cord involvement. Long-term corticosteroid use can actually weaken bones and contribute to osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the absence of neurological deficits, conservative management including pain control, physical therapy, and nutritional supplementation (such as Vitamin D and calcium) is often recommended for compression fractures of the vertebrae, particularly in elderly patients.
  • This approach focuses on pain relief, promoting healing, and preventing further osteoporotic fractures.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female came for a routine blood check-up. The lab technician collected about 5 ml of blood at 8 am in a plain vacutainer for various function tests including blood sugar and the sample was processed at 11 am and report was given at 12pm. All laboratory tests results were normal except blood glucose which was found to be 48 mg/dl. Which enzyme is responsible for the findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hexokinase

 

  • The low blood glucose level (48 mg/dl) in the sample that was collected and processed with a delay is likely due to glycolysis occurring in the blood sample by the cells (such as red and white blood cells) present in the sample.
  • Hexokinase is the enzyme involved in the first step of glycolysis, which converts glucose to glucose-6-phosphate, thereby reducing the measurable glucose in the sample over time if the sample is not processed promptly or if glycolysis is not inhibited after collection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucokinase: This enzyme also phosphorylates glucose but is primarily found in the liver and pancreatic beta cells, not in blood cells, and thus less relevant to the reduction of glucose in a stored blood sample.

 

Option C. Phosphofructokinase (PFK): Although PFK is a key regulatory enzyme in glycolysis, the initial step catalysed by hexokinase is more critical for trapping glucose within cells and starting glycolysis in a blood sample.

 

Option D. Enolase: Enolase is another enzyme involved in glycolysis, but it acts later in the pathway and is not responsible for the initial capture and phosphorylation of glucose in blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hexokinase activity in blood cells can lead to a reduction in the glucose concentration of a blood sample if it is not processed quickly.
  • This enzyme catalyses the first step in glycolysis, converting glucose to glucose-6-phosphate, thereby consuming glucose in the sample and potentially leading to falsely low glucose measurements if there is a delay in sample processing.

choices.text: Ventricular septal defect
Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC)
Atrial septal defect
Tetralogy of Fallot

questions.text: A 11-year-old child presents with shortness of breath and difficulty exercising. On examination, a fixed, split-second heart sound is heard, and there is a palpable thrill felt on the chest. Hilar dance was seen on fluoroscopy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atrial septal defect

 

  • The presence of a fixed, split-second heart sound (S2) is characteristic of an atrial septal defect (ASD), where there is a communication between the left and right atria.
  • This results in the left-to-right shunting of blood, which can lead to the symptoms described, such as shortness of breath and difficulty exercising.
  • The palpable thrill on the chest is due to turbulent flow across the septal defect, and "hilar dance" on fluoroscopy is due to increased pulmonary artery pulsations from the increased blood flow to the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ventricular septal defect: While VSDs can also present with a murmur and symptoms of shortness of breath, they typically do not cause a fixed, split-second heart sound.

 

Option B. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC): This condition would cause a more complex clinical picture, often with signs of severe cyanosis and heart failure, which are not described in this scenario.

 

Option D. Tetralogy of Fallot: This condition would likely present with cyanosis, especially during episodes of crying or feeding, due to the right-to-left shunting of blood (causing unoxygenated blood to enter the systemic circulation), which is not described in the scenario provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • An atrial septal defect typically presents with a fixed, split-second heart sound and can cause symptoms such as shortness of breath and difficulty with exercise due to increased pulmonary flow and right heart volume overload.
  • Hilar dance on fluoroscopy further supports the diagnosis by indicating increased blood flow through the pulmonary arteries.

questions.text: A Medical officer at an urban health clinic in a region with a high prevalence of leprosy is assessing patients for early signs of the disease. One patient presents with numbness and weakness in the hand. Given these symptoms, which peripheral nerve is most likely involved in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ulnar nerve

 

  • The ulnar nerve is frequently involved in leprosy, particularly in cases where the disease affects the peripheral nerves.
  • Symptoms such as numbness, weakness, or paralysis in the ring and little fingers, and the corresponding side of the hand, suggest ulnar nerve involvement due to its sensory and motor innervation patterns.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial nerve: The radial nerve primarily affects the back of the hand and the thumb, index, and middle fingers, which does not match the described symptoms.

 

Option B. Median nerve: The median nerve affects the lateral palm and the thumb, index, middle, and part of the ring fingers, not primarily the ring and little fingers.

 

Option C. Axillary nerve: The axillary nerve mainly innervates the deltoid and teres minor muscles and the skin around the deltoid area, unrelated to the hand's symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MC nerve involved in leprosy: Ulnar Nerve

choices.text: Deep vein thrombosis with pulmonary embolism

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman with a history of three uncomplicated full-term pregnancies presents with shortness of breath, lower extremity edema, and palpitations that began three weeks postpartum. She reports no prior history of cardiac disease. Physical examination reveals a heart rate of 110 bpm and signs of volume overload. Laboratory tests indicate a hemoglobin level of 9 g/dL. An echocardiogram shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35%. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Peripartum cardiomyopathy

 

  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy is a form of heart failure that occurs during the last month of pregnancy or within five months postpartum, without other identifiable causes for heart failure.
  • The diagnosis is supported by the finding of left ventricular systolic dysfunction with an ejection fraction (EF) typically below 45%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute myocardial infarction: Less likely without chest pain or a history of cardiac disease; typically, doesn't occur in the context of the postpartum period as the primary presentation.

 

Option B. Deep vein thrombosis with pulmonary embolism: Can present with dyspnea and may cause right heart strain but would not typically cause a reduced EF.
