Option C. Amniotic fluid embolism: Usually occurs during labor or immediately postpartum, with a rapid onset of respiratory distress, altered mental status, and coagulopathy, which are not described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peripartum cardiomyopathy, includes the development of heart failure symptoms towards the end of pregnancy or in the months following delivery, particularly in the absence of other causes of heart failure.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with severe head trauma is admitted to the intensive care unit and placed on mechanical ventilation. She requires high doses of anesthetic agent for sedation. On the third day of admission, she develops acute refractory bradycardia, lipemic plasma, metabolic acidosis, and rhabdomyolysis. Her renal function is deteriorating rapidly despite adequate fluid resuscitation and vasopressors. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Propofol infusion syndrome

 

  • Characterized by severe metabolic acidosis, cardiac failure, rhabdomyolysis, hyperlipidemia, and renal failure, often associated with high-dose or prolonged infusion of propofol.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Malignant Hyperthermia: A rapid onset hypermetabolic condition typically triggered by exposure to certain anesthetics like halothane or succinylcholine, not propofol.

 

Option B. Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN): Usually presents with renal failure due to ischemia or nephrotoxic agents but would not account for the full spectrum of symptoms presented.

 

Option D. Septic Shock: While septic shock can present with multiorgan dysfunction and metabolic acidosis, it would not typically present with lipemic plasma or be directly related to propofol infusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective is to identify and understand the clinical presentation and complications of propofol infusion syndrome, a rare but serious and potentially fatal condition associated with high-dose or prolonged propofol administration.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with a history of hypertension presents with sudden-onset unconsciousness and neck stiffness. The rest of his neurological examination is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)

 

  • SAH typically presents with a sudden, severe headache often described as the "worst headache of life," followed by loss of consciousness and nuchal rigidity due to meningeal irritation by blood in the subarachnoid space.
  • Hypertension is a risk factor for SAH as well as other types of strokes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intraparenchymal bleed: Can present with varying symptoms based on location but usually has focal neurological deficits.

 

Option C. Extradural hemorrhage: Typically associated with a history of trauma and may present with a lucid interval followed by deterioration in consciousness, rather than sudden unconsciousness.

 

Option D. Subdural hemorrhage: Often occurs after trauma, can present acutely, but more commonly presents with a more insidious onset of symptoms over days to weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • SAH should be considered in patients presenting with sudden-onset headache, unconsciousness, and nuchal rigidity, especially in the context of hypertension.

questions.text: During a routine immunization schedule planning, a healthcare professional assesses the records of patients with immunocompromising conditions. It is essential to identify which patients can safely receive vaccinations. For which of the following conditions is immunization not typically contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Complement deficiency

 

  • Complement deficiency does not usually present a contraindication for vaccinations.
  • Patients with complement deficiencies are more susceptible to infections, hence vaccinations are crucial in providing protection against various pathogens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome: This condition may compromise the immune system, making the administration of live vaccines potentially dangerous.

 

Option C. Ataxia telangiectasia: Patients with this condition are typically advised against live vaccines due to the risk of neurological deterioration.

 

Option D. DiGeorge syndrome: The severity of T-cell immunodeficiency in DiGeorge syndrome may necessitate the avoidance of live vaccines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • T lymphocyte (cell-mediated and humoral) related disorders with partial defect: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, Ataxia telangiectasia, Digeorge syndrome – Live vaccines are contraindicated
  • Complement deficiency: All routine vaccines effective; Pneumococcal and meningococcal vaccines recommended

choices.text: PGE2 intracervical gel
PGE1 vaginal tablet
Inj. Oxytocin infusion
Artificial rupture of membranes

questions.text: A 25-year-old primi is undergoing induction of labor for past dates. Her Bishop score is 1. Which would not be a preferred method?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Artificial rupture of membranes

 

  • Artificial rupture of membranes (ARM), also known as amniotomy, should not be performed when the Bishop score is low (less than 6), as it implies that the cervix is not yet favorable for delivery.
  • It could lead to an increased risk of complications such as cord prolapse or infection without significantly advancing labor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PGE2 intracervical gel: This is a method used to ripen the cervix and is appropriate when the Bishop score is low.

 

Option B. PGE1 vaginal tablet: Similar to PGE2, PGE1 (such as misoprostol) is used for cervical ripening and can be used when the Bishop score is low.

 

Option C. Inj. Oxytocin infusion: This can be used to induce labor, but typically after the cervix has been ripened if the Bishop score is low. It may be used in conjunction with cervical ripening agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When inducing labor, the Bishop score is used to assess the readiness of the cervix.
  • A low Bishop score indicates an unfavorable cervix, suggesting that cervical ripening methods such as PGE2 or PGE1 should be used before attempting more aggressive methods like ARM or oxytocin infusion.
  • ARM is not preferred with a low Bishop score due to increased risks without adequate cervical readiness.

questions.text: Which of these is not a complication of H. Pylori infection of the antrum?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GERD

 

  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is not typically considered a direct complication of H. pylori infection of the antrum.
  • In fact, it may reduce the incidence of GERD.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Chronic gastritis: H. pylori infection is a leading cause of chronic gastritis, particularly affecting the antrum of the stomach. Chronic gastritis can lead to inflammation, mucosal damage, and eventual atrophy of the gastric mucosa, contributing to symptoms and complications associated with H. pylori infection.

 

Option C. Adenocarcinoma of stomach: Chronic H. pylori infection, especially involving the antrum, is a well-established risk factor for the development of gastric adenocarcinoma. Prolonged inflammation and mucosal changes associated with H. pylori infection can lead to the progression of gastric mucosal changes to dysplasia and ultimately adenocarcinoma.

 

Option D. MALToma of stomach: Mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma, also known as MALToma, is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that can arise in the stomach, often in association with chronic H. pylori infection. H. pylori-induced chronic inflammation can stimulate the proliferation of lymphoid tissue and contribute to the development of MALT lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • H. Pylori can lead to chronic gastritis, peptic ulcer, and stomach cancers.

choices.text: Atrium Bulging into Aorta
Aortic Sinus Bulging into Left Atrium
Aortic Sinus Bulging into Right Atrium

questions.text: What causes the appearance of the torus aorticus in the heart?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortic Sinus Bulging into Right Atrium

 

  • Torus aorticus is produced by bulging of the right posterior aortic sinus.
  • It is seen in the anterosuperior part of the interatrial septum in the right atrium.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Atrium Bulging into Aorta: Normally, there is no structural feature in which an atrium bulges into the aorta. The atria and the aorta are separate chambers with distinct functions.

 

Option B. Aortic Sinus Bulging into Left Atrium are the dilations at the root of the aorta, just above the aortic valve. While these sinuses are close to the left atrium, they do not bulge into it. The structure of the heart prevents such an occurrence under normal conditions, and such a bulging would likely indicate a pathological condition.

 

Option D. Aortic Wall Tear, also known as an aortic dissection, where the inner layer of the aorta tears, causing blood to flow between the layers of the wall of the aorta. This condition does not lead to the formation of the torus aorticus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic Sinus Bulging into Right Atrium:  

 

  • The torus aorticus is caused by the bulging of the right posterior aortic sinus into the right atrium.
  • The aortic sinus, one of the three aortic sinuses, is located near the right atrium.
  • The bulging of this sinus into the right atrium can create a noticeable impression, known as the torus aorticus, on the wall of the right atrium.

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, page no. 263

choices.text: Perthes Disease
Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphyses
Observation Hip
Tuberculosis Hip

questions.text: A 12-year-old 70 kg child presents with limitation of abduction and internal rotation. There is tenderness in Scarpa’s triangle. On flexing the hip, the limb is externally rotated. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphyses

 

  • Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE) is a condition commonly seen in overweight or rapidly growing adolescents.
  • It presents with pain in the hip or knee and a characteristic gait.
  • The child may have limited hip motion, especially in abduction and internal rotation.
  • On flexion of the hip, there may be obligatory external rotation, which is a classic sign of SCFE.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perthes disease: This is a condition where the blood supply to the femoral head is temporarily disrupted, leading to avascular necrosis. It presents with a limp and pain, but the clinical presentation differs slightly from SCFE, and it typically affects children aged 4 to 8 years.

 

Option C. Observation hip: This option seems to be a typo or incorrect; it may refer to "observed" hip issues without a specific diagnosis. In the context of the provided symptoms, it doesn't apply.

 

Option D. Tuberculosis hip: Tuberculosis of the hip would present with chronic pain and progressive joint destruction over time, often associated with systemic symptoms of TB. It doesn't typically present with the acute symptoms described for SCFE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical presentation of pain, limited abduction and internal rotation of the hip, and external rotation on flexion is characteristic of Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE), particularly in an overweight or rapidly growing adolescent.
  • This condition requires prompt diagnosis and treatment to prevent further slippage and potential complications.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with sudden difficulty in understanding spoken language and expressing thoughts coherently. Neurological examination reveals no motor deficits, and the patient is intact. Imaging studies indicate damage to the posterior part of the left cerebral hemisphere. The sensory speech area is located in which lobe of the cerebral cortex?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Temporal Lobe

 

  • The sensory speech area, also known as Wernicke's area, is located in the posterior part of the left temporal lobe.
  • It is crucial for understanding spoken language, and damage to this area can lead to difficulties in language comprehension and fluent speech production.
  • Wernicke's area is located in the temporal lobe, shown here in grey:

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Frontal lobe: Incorrect. The frontal lobe contains the motor speech area (Broca's area) involved in speech production, but it is not primarily responsible for understanding language.

 

Option B. Parietal lobe: Incorrect. The parietal lobe is involved in processing sensory information and spatial orientation but not in primary language comprehension.

 

Option C. Occipital lobe: Incorrect. The occipital lobe is the center for visual processing and is not directly involved in language comprehension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The objective is to understand the localization and function of key areas in the cerebral cortex, specifically the role of the temporal lobe and Wernicke's area in language comprehension.

questions.text: Non-healing sinus is a common clinical feature in chronic osteomyelitis. The most common frequent cause for this presentation is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presence of sequestrum

 

  • In chronic osteomyelitis, the presence of sequestrum, which is a piece of dead bone that has become separated from healthy bone during the process of necrosis, is a common cause for non-healing sinuses.
  • The sequestrum acts as a foreign body and harbours bacteria, making it difficult for the infection to resolve and often leading to the formation of a sinus tract that drains to the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resistant Organisms: While resistant organisms can complicate the treatment of osteomyelitis, they are not the direct cause of non-healing sinuses. The treatment failure due to resistant organisms would likely result in persistent infection and inflammation but not specifically in the formation of non-healing sinuses.

 

Option B. Retained Foreign Body: Although a retained foreign body can also act as a nidus for infection and contribute to the persistence of infection, it is less common than sequestrum in the context of chronic osteomyelitis.

 

Option D. Intraosseous Cavities: Intraosseous cavities can form as a result of osteomyelitis and may contribute to the persistence of the disease. However, they are not as directly implicated in the formation of non-healing sinuses as the presence of sequestrum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of sequestrum is a significant factor in the persistence of non-healing sinuses in chronic osteomyelitis.
  • Identification and surgical removal of sequestrum are essential steps in the management of chronic osteomyelitis to allow for healing and resolution of the infection.

questions.text: In the pediatric clinic, a mother brings her infant for routine vaccinations. As an intern, you engage in conversation with her, and during the chat, the baby grasps a toy and brings it to their mouth, demonstrating a developmental milestone. The mother, cautious about hygiene, quickly removes the toy from the baby's grasp. This event leads you to reflect on the developmental milestones pertaining to fine motor skills. At what age does an infant typically develop a mature pincer grasp?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 12 months

 

  • Grasping object between thumb and index finger (Mature Pincer grasp) develops by 12 months.

 

 

  • Immature grasp at 6 months (Palmer grasp).

 

 

  • Intermediate grasp at 8 months, beginning to use radial aspect of the hand.

 

 

  • Mature Grasp at 1 year of age, note the use of thumb and index finger (Pincer grasp).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. 5 months: At 5-6 months of age, mouthing develops.

 

Option B. 7 months: At 7 months of age, baby develop unidextrous approach by 6 months.

 

Option C. 9 months: At 9 months of age, immature pincer grasp develops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fine Motor Milestones:

 

  • Birth: Grasp reflex present
  • 3 months: Grasp reflex disappears
  • 4 months: Bidextrous approach
  • 6 months: Unidextrous approach
  • 9 months: Immature pincer grasp
  • 12-13 months: Mature Pincer Grasp, Casting appear.
  • 15 months: Feeds himself with cup, slight spillage
  • 18 months: Use of Spoon, slight spillage Scribbles
  • 2 years: Vertical stroke, Turn one page of book at a time
  • 3, 4, 5 years: Universal milestones:
  • 3 years: draws circle
  • 4 years: draws ‘+’ and square/rectangle
  • 5 years: draws ‘x’ and triangle

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric emergency department with a sudden onset of seizures. His medical history is unremarkable, and there has been no prior incidence of seizures. On examination, his blood pressure is notably elevated at 200/140 mm Hg in the right arm. However, when attempting to palpate the femoral pulses, they are not detectable. Based on the presentation and physical findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coarctation of Aorta

 

  • Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital condition characterized by the narrowing of the aorta, which can lead to hypertension in the upper extremities and weak or absent femoral pulses, as described in the case.
  • The blood pressure discrepancy between the upper and lower body and the absence of palpable femoral pulses are classic signs of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Takayasu Arteritis: This typically presents in adolescents and young women and involves inflammation of the aorta and its branches, which could also lead to weak pulses. However, the age and acute presentation are less typical for Takayasu arteritis.

 

Option B. Renal parenchymal disease: While it can cause hypertension, it usually does not lead to absent femoral pulses.

 

Option C. Grand mal seizures: While the child presented with seizures, the blood pressure findings and absent femoral pulses point towards a cardiovascular cause for the symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Coarctation of the aorta is a condition that can present with high blood pressure in the upper extremities and diminished or absent pulses in the lower extremities.
  • The presence of seizures in this context may be secondary to the hypertension or an associated condition such as a cerebral aneurysm.

questions.text: A patient has repeated episodes of multiple infections involving the lungs, liver and bones requiring hospitalization. His past medical history is significant for excessive inflammation with granulomas, gingivitis, aphthous ulcers, and seborrheic dermatitis. Deficiency of which of the following enzymes would result in these features?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NADPH oxidase

 

  • The patient's presentation of repeated infections, excessive inflammation with granulomas, gingivitis, aphthous ulcers, and seborrheic dermatitis is suggestive of Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD).
  • CGD is a genetic disorder caused by a deficiency or malfunction of NADPH oxidase, an enzyme complex in phagocytes (neutrophils, monocytes, and macrophages) essential for producing reactive oxygen species to kill certain bacteria and fungi.
  • The lack of functional NADPH oxidase leads to an inability to effectively destroy these pathogens, resulting in recurrent infections and granuloma formation due to the body's exaggerated attempt to contain the infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle glycogen phosphorylase: Deficiency of this enzyme leads to McArdle's disease, a type of glycogen storage disease affecting muscle metabolism, not associated with recurrent infections or granuloma formation.

 

Option C. Myeloperoxidase: Myeloperoxidase deficiency can lead to increased susceptibility to certain infections but is typically less severe than CGD and does not usually result in the broad range of symptoms described in the patient.

 

Option D. Xanthine oxidase: Deficiency in this enzyme is not associated with increased infection risk or the clinical features described. Xanthine oxidase is involved in purine metabolism, and its inhibition is used in the treatment of gout.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • NADPH oxidase deficiency, seen in Chronic Granulomatous Disease, leads to recurrent infections and excessive inflammatory responses, including granuloma formation, due to the impaired microbial killing capacity of phagocytes.

questions.text: A drug that binds to and inhibits Gp IIb/IIIa glycoprotein, and is responsible for platelet antiaggregatory effects is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tirofiban

 

  • Tirofiban is an antiplatelet drug that specifically targets and inhibits the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor on the surface of platelets.
  • By blocking this receptor, tirofiban prevents the binding of fibrinogen and von Willebrand factor, which are crucial for platelet aggregation and thrombus formation.
  • This mechanism makes it effective in reducing the risk of arterial thrombosis, especially in acute coronary syndromes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clopidogrel: An antiplatelet agent that inhibits the ADP receptor on platelets, thus preventing ADP-mediated activation of the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa complex, but it does not directly inhibit glycoprotein IIb/IIIa.

 

Option B. Enoxaparin: A low molecular weight heparin that works by enhancing the activity of antithrombin III, leading to inhibition of thrombin and factor Xa. It does not directly inhibit platelet aggregation.

 

Option C. Fondaparinux: A synthetic pentasaccharide that selectively inhibits factor Xa via antithrombin III but has no effect on platelets or glycoprotein IIb/IIIa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tirofiban is an antiplatelet drug that acts by directly inhibiting the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor on platelets, preventing platelet aggregation and thrombus formation, particularly in the setting of acute coronary syndromes.

questions.text: A 49-year-old individual with a history of alcohol use presents with severe epistaxis and spontaneous skin ecchymoses. Lab tests indicate significantly prolonged clotting times. Given these findings, which protein's function, crucial for blood coagulation, is most likely impaired?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gamma-glutamyl carboxylase

 

  • This patient's presentation of heavy nasal bleeding, scattered ecchymoses, and prolonged prothrombin time, along with a history of alcohol abuse, is indicative of vitamin K deficiency leading to impaired synthesis of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X.
  • Gamma-glutamyl carboxylase is an enzyme that uses vitamin K to catalyse the carboxylation of glutamic acid residues on prothrombin and other vitamin K-dependent clotting factors, making them functional. Impairment in this enzyme's activity due to vitamin K deficiency or liver disease can lead to the clinical picture seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protein S: This is a vitamin K-dependent anticoagulant protein, deficiency of which leads to increased clot formation, not bleeding.

 

Option B. Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA): This enzyme helps break down blood clots; impaired function would lead to thrombosis rather than bleeding.

 

Option C. Von Willebrand factor: It is involved in platelet adhesion; its deficiency leads to von Willebrand disease, which presents with mucocutaneous bleeding but typically does not prolong PT and PTT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The role of gamma-glutamyl carboxylase in the post-translational modification of clotting factors, an essential process for their activation that requires vitamin K.

questions.text: A 61-year-old smoker presents with hemoptysis, central obesity, and a round face with a moon-like appearance. He has a suspected left lung tumor with "salt and pepper" chromatin pattern on biopsy. What is the most appropriate management for him?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cisplatin and radiotherapy

 

  • A patient presenting with Cushing's syndrome (central obesity, moon face) and a "salt and pepper" chromatin pattern on lung biopsy is suggestive of a small cell lung cancer (SCLC), which often produces ectopic ACTH leading to Cushing's syndrome.
  • SCLC is aggressive and responds best to chemotherapy and radiotherapy.
  • Cisplatin is a common chemotherapeutic agent used in the treatment of SCLC, and in combination with radiotherapy, it can manage both local and distant disease aspects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prednisone: Prednisone is a steroid that could potentially worsen the patient's condition by stimulating appetite and further increasing central obesity. It is not a treatment for SCLC.

 

Option B. Surgical resection: SCLC is typically widespread at diagnosis and thus is not considered a good candidate for surgical resection as an initial treatment.

 

Option D. Tamoxifen: Tamoxifen is an anti-estrogen medication used primarily in the treatment of breast cancer and is not used in the treatment of lung cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The treatment of choice for small cell lung cancer (SCLC), especially in the limited stage or for symptom control in extensive stage, is a combination of chemotherapy and radiotherapy, not surgical resection or hormonal therapy such as tamoxifen.

questions.text: A 45-year-old content creator is scheduled for mastoidectomy. For the surgical team preparing the operating room, which of the following instruments would not be necessary for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D)

 

  • The given image is that of a Laparoscopic trocar.
  • It is used in minimally invasive abdominal surgeries for inserting instruments into the abdominal cavity, this would not be required during mastoid surgery.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Otoscope: Used for examining the ear canal and tympanic membrane, an otoscope is essential in the preoperative assessment, but it may not be directly utilized during the mastoid surgery itself.

 

Option B. Chisel and mallet: Typically used in mastoid surgeries to remove the bony mastoid air cells and gain access to the middle ear and mastoid cavity.

 

Option C. Suction irrigator: Necessary for clearing the surgical field of blood and debris and for reducing the risk of thermal injury during drilling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When preparing for a mastoidectomy, various specialized otologic surgical instruments are required.
  • However, instruments like a laparoscopic trocar, which are used in abdominal surgeries, would not be necessary.
